head.hi: The numerals refer to the books, the figures to the chapters.

div1.head: ABDERITES complain of the rapacity and cruelty of Hortensius
div1.p: and redress is ordered by the senate, 43.4.

div1.head: Abelox
div1.p: a Spaniard, contrives to put into Scipio's hands the hostages left by Hannibal at Saguntum, 22.22.

div1.head: Aborigines
div1.p: united to the Trojans, lose their king Latinus in battle, 1.1, 2.

div1.head: Abrupolis
div1.p: an ally of the Romans, oppressed by Perseus, 42.13.
Charged by him as the aggressor, 41.

div1.head: Abydus
div1.p: city of Mysia, besieged by Philip, 31.14.
They kill their wives, children, and themselves, 18.
The Rhodians insist on the Macedonian garrison being withdrawn, 32.33.
Which is made an article in a treaty of peace, 33.30.
It is besieged by the Romans, 37.12.

div1.head: Acarnania
div1.p: Two Acarnanians killed at Athens, for entering the temple of Ceres, which gives rise to the Macedonian war, 31.14.

div1.head: Acerrae
div1.p: city, admitted to the freedom of Rome, 8.17.

div1.head: Achaeans
div1.p: assisted by Philip against the Aetolians, 27.29.
In a council at Sicyon they determine in favour of the Romans, 32.19, 23.
Refuse audience to the ambassadors of Perseus, 41.25.

div1.head: Acilius
div1.p: historian, his work translated into Latin by Claudius, 25.39.

div1.head: Man. Acilius Glabrio
div1.p: Arrives with his army in Thessaly, 14.
His proceedings in Greece, 15–20. When he defeats Antiochus and the $Aetolians at Thermopylae, reduces Heraclea, 22.24.
and composes the affairs of Greece, 35.
Takes Lamia and Amphissa from the Aetolians, 37.5.
Dedicates a temple to Piety, in which he places a gilded statue of his father, the first of the kind seen in Italy, 40.34.

div1.head: Adramytteum
div1.p: city of Asia, in the plain of Thebes, celebrated by Homer, 37.19, 21.

div1.head: Aediles
div1.p: Are ordered to keep the decrees of the senate in the temple of Ceres, and their persons are declared inviolable, 55.

div1.head: Aediles
div1.p: Commence a practice of ornamenting the forum on festivals, 9.40.

div1.head: Aegimurus island
div1.p: At the mouth of the harbour of Carthage, 30.24.

div1.head: P. Aelius Paetus
div1.p: one of the first plebeian quaestors, 4.54.

div1.head: P. Aelius Paetus
div1.p: Master of horse, resigns on his election appearing faulty, 9.7.

div1.head: Q. Aelius
div1.p: charged by the consul with the care of Perseus when a prisoner, 45.8.

div1.head: L. Aemilius
div1.p: Being again interrex, he holds the election of consuls, 8.23.

div1.head: L. Aemilius Regillus
div1.p: commander of the fleet employed against Antiochus, 37.1, 14.

div1.head: L. Aemilius Paullus
div1.p: Commissioner to settle the affairs of Asia, 37.55.
His conduct in the war against Perseus, 13–42. When he gains a complete victory, he receives Perseus with courtesy, 45.7.
He, with fifteen commissioners, adjusts the affairs of Macedonia, 29.
Exhibits games at Amphipolis with extraordinary magnificence, 32.
Triumphs over Perseus, and loses his two sons, 40.

div1.head: Mamercus Aemilius Paullus
div1.p: He shortens the term of the censorship, 24.

div1.head: Man. Aemilius Paullus
div1.p: Chosen a third time prince of the senate, 43.15.

div1.head: Aequi
div1.p: A quarrel, and furious battle, between them and the Volscians, 40.
They make war on the Romans, and harass the Latins, 48, 53, 58.
In conjunction with the Volscians, they ravage the lands of the Romans and Hernicians, 6.
Seize the citadel of Tusculum, and suffer a severe overthrow, 23.
Surround the consul Minucius in his camp, 26.
Are surrounded and sent under the yoke, by Q. Cincinnatus, dictator, 28.
They obtain a truce of eight years, 30.
They join the Lavicans, and waste the lands of Tusculum, 45.
Are driven out of that country, 47.
Are compelled to retire with loss, 28.
Suffer the same fate at Vitellia, 29, 31.
Are almost entirely cut off in battle, 9.45.
and are finally subdued by C. Junius, dictator, 10.1.
How they were enabled to recruit their armies, 5.12.

div1.head: Aesculapius
div1.p: His temple adorned with pictures by Lucretius, 43.4.

div1.head: Aetolians
div1.p: form an alliance with the Romans, 26.24.
Make war on Macedonia and Acarnania, 25.
Solicit the aid of Antiochus, Philip, and Nabis, against the Romans, 35.12.
Are defeated, together with Antiochus, at Thermopylae, by Acilius, 36.19.

div1.head: Africa
div1.p: furnished with a strong army by Hannibal, 21.22.
The consul, Servilius, is unsuccessful there, 22.31.
It is ravaged by M. Valerius Messala, 27.5.
Scipio goes into Africa, 29.26, 27. See Scipio, Hannibal.

div1.head: Agathocles
div1.p: king of Syracuse, went into Africa, 28.43.

div1.head: Agathyrna
div1.p: town in Sicily, filled with miscreants, 26.40; 27.12.

div1.head: Agesipolis
div1.p: rightful heir to the crown of Lacedaemon, an exile, 34.26.

div1.head: Alabanda
div1.p: Alabandans inform the senate, that they had built a temple to the city of Rome as a deity, and instituted games in honour of it, 43.6.

div1.head: Albans
div1.p: Combat of the Horatii and Curiatii, 24.
Their chiefs brought into the senate, 30.

div1.head: L. Albinius
div1.p: carries the vestal virgins in a waggon to Caere, 5.40.

div1.head: C. Albius Calenus
div1.p: a leader of the mutiny at Sucro, 28.24.

div1.head: Albula
div1.p: old name of the Tiber, i 3.

div1.head: Alexander
div1.p: king of Epirus, comes into Italy, 8.3.
His wife sister to Alexander the Great.

div1.head: Alexander the
div1.p: Compared with the Roman generals of that age, 9.17, 20.

div1.head: Alexander of Megalopolis
div1.p: father-in-law of Amynander, pretends to be a descendant of Alexander the Great, and is led into hopes of the crown of Macedonia, 35.48.

div1.head: Allucius
div1.p: Celtiberian prince, receives his spouse from Scipio, 26.50.

div1.head: Alorcus and Alcon mediate between Hannibal and the Saguntines
Alps
div1.p: Crossed by Hannibal in fifteen days, 21.38.

div1.head: Altar
div1.p: greatest, dedicated to Hercules by Evander, 1.7; 9.29.

div1.head: Ambassadors
div1.p: ought to be considered as inviolable, 2.4.
Ambassadors from enemies were admitted to audience in the temple of Bellona, 30.22.

div1.head: Amiternian lands
div1.p: The inhabitants promise soldiers to Scipio, 28.45.

div1.head: Amphipolis
div1.p: The inhabitants refuse to give refuge to Perseus, 45.

div1.head: Amynander
div1.p: Joins the Romans, and wastes Thessaly, 32.14.

div1.head: Amyntas
div1.p: king of Macedonia, father of Philip, 38.34; 45.9.

div1.head: Ancilia
div1.p: the sacred shields that fell from heaven, 1.20; 5.52.

div1.head: Sp. Ancius
div1.p: Roman ambassador, slain by order of Tolumnius, 4.17.

div1.head: Andranodorus
div1.p: son-in-law of Hiero, king of Syracuse, and guardian of his son Hieronymus, 24.4.

div1.head: Andros
div1.p: Taken by the Romans, and bestowed on Attalus, 31.45; 32.16; 36.20.

div1.head: Androsthenes
div1.p: Macedonian commander of a garrison in Corinth, obliges Quintius and Attalus to raise the siege, 32.23.

div1.head: L. Anicius
div1.p: Recovers the Roman ambassadors seized by Gentius, 32.
Leads Gentius and his family in triumph, 43.

div1.head: L. Annius
div1.p: praetor of the Latins, summoned to Rome, 8.3.
Demands that one consul, and half the senate of Rome, may be chosen out of Latium, 5.

div1.head: T. Annius
div1.p: commissioner of a colony, flies to Mutina from an insurrection of the Boians, 21.25.

div1.head: Antians
div1.p: Their ships are taken from them, with the prows of which the pulpit in the forum is ornamented, 14.

div1.head: Anticyra
div1.p: island, taken by the Romans, and delivered to the Aetolians, 26.26; 28.28.

div1.head: Antigonus
div1.p: Informs Philip, king of Macedonia, of the crimes of Perseus against Demetrius, 55.
Destined to the throne by Philip, 56.

div1.head: Antimachus
div1.p: Macedonian commander of the holy brigade, 42.46.

div1.head: Antiochus
div1.p: king of Syria, in league with Philip of Macedonia, 31.14.
Endeavours to make himself master of all Asia, 33.38.
Is solicited by the Aetolians to join in alliance against the Romans, 35.12.
A conference between his minister and ambassadors from Rome, 16.
Makes a vain attempt on Chalcis, 46.
At the approach of the Romans, raises the siege of Larissa, 10.
Instigated by Hannibal, he prepares to renew the war, 41.
Proposes a treaty of peace, which is rejected by Emilius, 37.19.

His fleet is defeated by the Rhodians, 23,24. Again by the Romans, 30. He makes overtures for peace, and sends back the son of Scipio Africanus, who was a prisoner in his hands, 34. The treaty is broken off, and his offers to Scipio rejected, 35, 36. He is finally defeated by Scipio, 43. Terms of peace granted to him, 45. His proceedings in Egypt, 45.11.

div1.head: Anxur
div1.p: afterwards Tarracina, taken by the Romans, 4.59.

div1.head: Apamea
div1.p: so called from Apamea, sister of king Seleucus, formerly Celenae, 35.15; 38.13.

div1.head: Apennine mount
div1.p: Hannibal attempts to pass over it, 21.58.

div1.head: Apollo Pythius
div1.p: A tenth of the spoil offered to him, 23.

div1.head: Appeal
div1.p: to the people established by law, 2.8; 3.55; 10.9.
Nor at a greater distance from the city than one mile, 3.20.

div1.head: Apulians
div1.p: form an alliance with the Romans, 8.25.

div1.head: Archimedes
div1.p: the famous mathematician, baffles the attacks of the Romans on Syracuse, 24.34.

div1.head: Ardea
div1.p: In a dispute between the Ardeans and Aricians, the Romans make a scandalous decision, 3.71, 72.
The alliance is renewed with them, 7.
The Ardeans, under the command of Camillus, attack the Gauls, 5.43.

div1.head: L. Arennius
div1.p: prefect or general of the allies, 27.26, 27.

div1.head: Argei
div1.p: places appointed for the performance of sacrifices, 1.21.

div1.head: Argos
div1.p: Betrayed to Philip, and given in trust to Nabis, 32.38.
Robbed by him and his wife, 40.
A fruitless attempt to deliver it, 34.25.
It is taken by the Romans, and given up to the Achaeans, 34.41.

div1.head: Ariarathes
div1.p: Is fined, and admitted into alliance by the Romans, 38.39.
Sends his son to Rome to be educated, 42.19.

div1.head: Aristo
div1.p: of Tyre, sent, by Hannibal, to Carthage, 34.61.

div1.head: Aristodemus
div1.p: tyrant of Cumae, detains the Roman ships to gratify Tarquinius, 2.34.

div1.head: Aristomachus
div1.p: leader of the populace at Croto, betrays the city to Hannibal, 24.2, 3.

div1.head: Aristoteles
div1.p: officer in the army of Antiochus, 36.21.

div1.head: Armilustrum
div1.p: a festival, and a place so called, 27.37.

div1.head: Army
div1.p: Roman, and all its parts, described, with the arms and method of marshalling and fighting, 8.8.

div1.head: Arnus river
div1.p: its overflowing very much obstructs Hannibal's march, 22.2, 3.

div1.head: Arpi
div1.p: Is taken by Q. Fabius, consul, 24.46, 47.

div1.head: Arretians
div1.p: meditate a revolt, but are kept in awe by Marcellus, 27.21.

div1.head: Artetarus
div1.p: Illyrian, killed by order of Philip, 42.13.

div1.head: Aruns
div1.p: of Clusium, advises the Gauls to besiege Clusium, and acts as their guide, 5.33.

div1.head: Ascanius
div1.p: son of Aeneas, builds Alba Longa, 1.3.

div1.head: Assembly
div1.p: Passes the laws of the twelve tables, 3.34.
and others, tries persons accused of treason, 6.20.

div1.head: Astapa
div1.p: The inhabitants set fire to the city, and put themselves to death, 23.

div1.head: Atella
div1.p: The inhabitants are removed to Calatia, 27.3.

div1.head: Athenians
div1.p: send ambassadors to compromise disputes between Philip and the Aetolians, 27.30.
Implore the protection of Rome against Philip, 31.5.
Origin of their war with Philip, 14.
Their complaints in the Aetotolian council, 30.
They intercede with Scipio in favour of the Aetolians, 37.6.

div1.head: Athens
div1.p: ambassadors sent thither from Rome to collect laws, 3.31.
It is saved from being surprised, by Philip, by the expedition of a courier, 31.24, 26.
It is visited by P. Aemilius, 45.27.

div1.head: C. Atilius
div1.p: praetor, brings succour to L. Manlius, 21.26.

div1.head: L. Atilius
div1.p: one of the first consular tribunes, 4.7.

div1.head: M. Atilius Regulus
div1.p: Conducts the war, according to the advice of Fabius, 23.21.

div1.head: M. Atilius Regulus
div1.p: Clears the city of foreign religious rites, 25.1.

div1.head: C. Atinius Labeo
div1.p: military tribune, throws the standard among the enemy, 34.46.

div1.head: C. Atrius Umber
div1.p: leader of a mutiny at Sucro, beheaded, 28.24, 29.

div1.head: Attalus
div1.p: Takes Opus, where he narrowly escapes being surprised by Philip, and returns to Asia, 28.7.
He escorts the Roman ambassadors to Pessinus, and gives them the sacred stone Cybele, 29.11.
Exhorts the Aetolians to join in the war against Philip, 15.
His ambassadors solicit aid from the Romans against Antiochus, 32.8.

div1.head: Attalus
div1.p: brother of Eumenes, comes to Rome, 35.23.
Again, with congratulations on the victory over Antiochus, 45.19.
His honourable conduct towards his brother, 20.

div1.head: Attius Tullius
div1.p: Entertains Coriolanus, inflames his countrymen against the Romans, 38.
Is joined in command with Coriolanus, 39.
The Aequans refuse to act under his command, 40.

div1.head: Aventine
div1.p: Added to the city, and given to the Latins, 33.

div1.head: Q. Aulius Cenetanus
div1.p: Master of horse, he kills the Samnite general, and is himself slain, 22.

div1.head: Ausetanians
div1.p: Roused to insurrection against the Romans, by Indibilis, 29.2.

div1.head: Axes
div1.p: never, after Publicola, carried before the magistrates in the city, 24.9.

div1.head: Cn. Baebius Tamphilus
div1.p: plebeian tribune, brings an action against the censors, 29.37.
Placed at the head of an army in Gaul, he is defeated with great slaughter, 32.7.

div1.head: Q. Baebius Herennius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, inveighs against the senate and the augurs, 22.34.

div1.head: A. Baeculonius
div1.p: standard-bearer, throws the standard into the enemy's camp, and is the first that enters, 41.4.

div1.head: Bantius of Nola
div1.p: inclined to favour Hannibal, is engaged by the kindness of Marcellus, 23.15.

div1.head: Barley given
div1.p: instead of wheat, to cohorts that lost their standards, 27.13.

div1.head: Beard
div1.p: not shaved by the ancient Romans, 5.4.
Afterwards suffered to grow long in time of mourning, 6.16.

div1.head: Bellovesus
div1.p: nephew of Ambigarus, king of the Celts, leads a body of them into Italy, 5.34.

div1.head: Blosii
div1.p: two brothers in Capua, detected in a conspiracy against the Romans, 27.3.

div1.head: Bocchar
div1.p: an officer sent by Syphax against Masinissa, 29.32.

div1.head: Books
div1.p: linen, deposited in the temple of Moneta, 4.20.

div1.head: Brachyllas
div1.p: Boeotarch, or chief magistrate of Boeotia, 33.27; 35.47.

div1.head: Brennus
div1.p: leader of the Gauls, defeats the Romans at the Allia, 5.38.
His insolence when weighing the ransom of the capital, 48.

div1.head: Bridges
div1.p: broken down to retard Hannibal's march, 26.9.

div1.head: Brixia
div1.p: Cenomanian Gauls settle in that quarter, 5.35.

div1.head: Brundusium
div1.p: The inhabitants commended by the Romans, 27.10.

div1.head: Bruttian states
div1.p: Proceedings of the Carthaginians in Bruttium, 24.1.

div1.head: Brutulus Papius
div1.p: who had advised the Samnites to break the truce with the Romans, avoids, by a voluntary death, being sent prisoner to Rome, 8.39.

div1.head: Busa
div1.p: Apulian woman, entertains at Canusium the remains of the defeated Roman army, 22.52.

div1.head: L. Caecilius Metellus
div1.p: after the battle of Cannae, proposes to abandon Italy, 22.53.

div1.head: Caedicius
div1.p: centurion, at the head of some Roman fugitives at Veii, routs the Etrurians, 5.45, 46.

div1.head: Caenomanians
div1.p: the only Gallic tribe that did not revolt to Hannibal, 21.55.
Are stripped of their arms, by M. Furius, who is ordered to restore them, and quit the country, 39.3.

div1.head: Caere
div1.p: entertains the Roman priests and vestals, 5.40.
An alliance of hospitality is formed with the inhabitants, and afterwards war declared against them, 7.19.
They assist Scipio in fitting out a fleet, 28.45.

div1.head: Calavii
div1.p: charged with setting fire to Rome, 26.27.

div1.head: Pacuvius Calavius
div1.p: acquires an ascendency over the senate and people of Campania, 23.2, 3.
Hinders his son Perolla from killing Hannibal, 9.

div1.head: Cales
div1.p: taken by the Romans, and a colony established, 8.16; 22.15; 23.31; 24.45; 26.9, 16; 27.9; 29.15.

div1.head: Campanians and Sidicinians overpowered by the Samnites
div1.p: Implore aid from the Romans, and are refused, 30, 31.
Surrender themselves as subjects to the Romans, 8.11.
Are deprived of a part of their lands, and made citizens of Rome without right of suffrage, 14.
Misconduct of their senate and populace, 23.24.
They suffocate the Roman soldiers, and invite Hannibal, 25.15.
At the instigation of Vibius Virius, twenty-seven senators poison themselves, 14.
A conspiracy of the Campanians discovered, 27.3.
A part of their lands sold, 28.46.

div1.head: Cannae
div1.p: Battle, 47, &c. Roman troops engaged there banished to Sicily, 23.31.
They beseech Marcellus to employ them, 25.6.
The knights who fled thence disgraced, 27.11.

div1.head: C. Canuleius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, procures a repeal of the law which prohibited the intermarriage of plebeians with patricians, 4.6.

div1.head: Canusium
div1.p: affords shelter to the Roman fugitives from Cannae, 22.50, 52.

div1.head: Capitol
div1.p: Is seized by Herdonius, a Sabine, with slaves and exiles, 3.15.
The lower part built with hewn stone, 6.4.

div1.head: Capitoline hill
div1.p: Given to the Sabines for their residence, 33.

div1.head: Capua
div1.p: Praefects appointed by the Romans to govern it, 9.20.
It is besieged by the Romans, 25.20, 22; 26.1, 4.

div1.head: Capusa
div1.p: son of Oesalces, king of Numidia, succeeds his father, and is slain, 29.29.

div1.head: Carteia
div1.p: a sea-port on the Atlantic Ocean, 28.30.

div1.head: Carthage
div1.p: Taken with immense booty, and the hostages of all the Spanish states, 46, 50.

div1.head: Carthaginians
div1.p: The Carthaginians are finally vanquished by Scipio, and compelled to submit to his terms of peace, 30.35, 37. See Hannibal, Mago, Hasdrubal. The Carthaginians send to Rome the first payment of the tribute, and receive some of their hostages, 32.2.
Offer ships and corn to the Romans, 36.4.
Send ambassadors to Rome, with complaints against him, 42.23.

div1.head: Carthalo
div1.p: Carthaginian general, conducts the prisoners to Rome, and is ordered to quit Italy, 22.58.

div1.head: C. Carvilius Spoletinus
div1.p: capitulates with Perseus for the garrison of Uscana, 43.18.

div1.head: Sp. Carvilius Spoletinus
div1.p: advises to choose half the senate out of the Latins, 23.22.

div1.head: Sp. Carvilius Spoletinus
div1.p: consul, takes Amiternum, and other towns in Samnium, 39.44.

div1.head: Carystians
div1.p: Grecian, harassed by descents of the Romans and Rhodians, 31.45; 32.16.

div1.head: Casilinum
div1.p: It is recovered by the Romans, 24.19.

div1.head: Cassander betrays Maronea to Philip
div1.p: and is poisoned by his order, 39.34.

div1.head: Sp. Cassius Longinus
div1.p: Is the first master of horse, 18.
A third time; he first proposes an Agrarian law, is found guilty of treason, and executed, 41.

div1.head: Castulo
div1.p: a strong city in Spain, joins the Romans, 24.41.

div1.head: Celtiberians
div1.p: shake off the yoke of the Carthaginians, 22.21.
Are engaged by the Roman generals, on the same terms that they had stipulated with the Carthaginians, 24.49.

div1.head: Censors
div1.p: A censor disgraced by his colleague, 29.37.
Term of the office reduced from five years to one year and a half, 4.24; 9.33.

div1.head: Centuries of knights
div1.p: Their numbers doubled by Servius Tullius, 42.
The people divided into centuries by the same, 42.

div1.head: Chalcis in Euboea
div1.p: whence the people of Cumae derive their origin, 8.22.

div1.head: Charilaus surrenders Palaepolis to the Romans
Cirta
div1.p: capital of Syphax, surrenders to Masinissa, 30.12.

div1.head: Claudia Quinta
div1.p: Roman matron, receives the Idaean Mother, 29.14.

div1.head: Claudian family
div1.p: always zealous champions for the patricians, 6.41.

div1.head: Appius Claudius
div1.p: formerly Atta Clausus, removes from Regillum to Rome, with a large number of clients, who are admitted citizens, and is made a senator, 2.16.

div1.head: Appius Claudius
div1.p: Is sent against the Volscians, and his army, through dislike to him, fly before the enemy, 59.

div1.head: Appius Claudius
div1.p: And puts himself to death in prison, 58.

div1.head: Appius Claudius
div1.p: son of the preceding, military tribune, 4.54.

div1.head: Appius Claudius
div1.p: grandson of the decemvir, opposes the admission of plebeians to the consulship, 6.40.

div1.head: Appius Claudius
div1.p: in the office of censor, makes the famous road, and aqueduct; through his advice, the Potitian family commit the charge of the rites of Hercules to public slaves, and become extinct, 9.29.

div1.head: Appius Claudius
div1.p: consul, first makes war against Carthage, 31.1.

div1.head: Appius Claudius
div1.p: Is wounded at the siege of Capua, 26.1.

div1.head: C. Claudius Nero
div1.p: Commands in Spain, and is baffled by Hasdrubal, 26.17.
Orders Hasdrubal's head to be thrown in the enemy's view, 51.

div1.head: M. Claudius Nero
div1.p: client of the decemvir, claims Virginia as his slave, 3.44.

div1.head: M. Claudius Marcellus
div1.p: is sent, after the battle of Cannae, to collect the remains of the army, 57.
Is chosen consul a second time, and abdicates, 31.
Is made consul a third time, 24.9.
Triumphs on the Alban mount, and enters the city in ovation, 26.21.
Is made consul a fifth time, 21.
Insnared by a stratagem, and slain. 26, 27.

div1.head: M. Claudius Marcellus
div1.p: son of the consul, military tribune, 26.26; 29.11, 20.

div1.head: Cleonymus
div1.p: Lacedaemonian general, brings an army into Italy, and takes Thuriae, but is driven out by the Patavians, 10.2.

div1.head: Cleopatra
div1.p: consort of Alexander, king of Epire, 8.24.

div1.head: Cloak of
div1.p: the Grecian fashion, charged as an instance of effeminacy on Scipio, 29.19.

div1.head: Gracchus Cloelius
div1.p: Aequan general, vanquished, and taken by Q. Cincinnatus, 3.28.

div1.head: Cloelius Tullius
div1.p: Roman ambassador, murdered by order of Tolumnius, 4.17.

div1.head: Titus Cloelius
div1.p: one of the first consular tribunes, 4.7.

div1.head: Clondicus
div1.p: Gallic general, in treaty with Perseus, 44.26.

div1.head: Cluvia
div1.p: taken by the Samnites, recovered by the Romans, 9.31.

div1.head: Cluvia and
div1.p: Oppia, Campanian women, have their liberty and property restored, 26.34.

div1.head: Cnossians
div1.p: refuse to restore the Roman prisoners, 37.60.

div1.head: Comitium
div1.p: part of the forum where the curias assembled, 6.15.

div1.head: Commentaries
div1.p: of Numa, published by Ancus Marcius, 1.32.

div1.head: Contenebra
div1.p: taken by the Romans, and plundered, against the will of the commanders, 6.4.

div1.head: Cornelia
div1.p: forced to drink the poison which she had prepared for her husband, 8.18.

div1.head: Aul. Cornelius Arvina
div1.p: herald, delivers up to the Samnites the sureties for the convention of Caudium, 9.10.

div1.head: Aul. Cornelius Cossus
div1.p: military tribune, kills Tolumnius, king of the Veientians, 4.19.

div1.head: Aul. Cornelius Cossus
div1.p: The first who waged war with the Samnites, 10.31.

div1.head: Cn. Cornelius Lentulus
div1.p: Quaestor, he fights Hannibal with doubtful success, 25.19.
Protests against the decree of the senate giving peace to the Carthaginians, 43.

div1.head: L. Cornelius Scipio
div1.p: sent by his brother against Hasdrubal, 21.32.
He acts in conjunction with his brother, 23.26, 29, 48, 49; 24.41—49.
Deserted by the Celtiberians, he and his army are cut off, 36.

div1.head: L. Cornelius Lentulus
div1.p: Advises to accept the terms dictated by Pontius, at Caudium, 9.4.

div1.head: L. Cornelius Lentulus
div1.p: succeeds Scipio in the government of Spain, 28.38.

div1.head: L. Cornelius Scipio
div1.p: Triumphs and assumes the title Asiaticus, 59.
Condemned for having accepted presents from Antiochus, 37.55.
Liberated by Tib. Gracchus, plebeian tribune, 60.
At the review of the knights, he is deprived of his horse, 39.44.

div1.head: L. Cornelius Merula
div1.p: His letter after he had defeated the Boians at Mutina, 35.6.

div1.head: P. Cornelius Scipio
div1.p: One of the first curule aediles, 7.1.

div1.head: P. Cornelius Lentulus
div1.p: Attempts in vain to overtake Hannibal in Gaul, 32.
And hastens back to the Po, 39.
Is defeated, and wounded at the Ticinus, 46.
Recommends to his colleague to avoid fighting, 52, 53.
Sails to Spain, and joins his brother, 22.22.

div1.head: P. Cornelius Lentulus
div1.p: son of the preceding, rescues his father from imminent danger at the Ticinus, 21.46.
After the battle of Cannae, he breaks up a conspiracy, formed for abandoning Italy, 22.53.
At twenty-four years of age is sent proconsul into Spain, 26.18.
Takes New Carthage in one day, 42.46.
Acts in Spain with extraordinary success, 27.17, 18; 28.1, 4, 12, 16.
Passes over to Africa, on a visit to Syphax, 17.
Dines at the same table with Hasdrubal, 18.
Forms an alliance between the Romans and Masinissa, 35.
On his return to Rome is elected consul, 38.
Prepares for a descent on Africa, xxix. l. Passes over thither, and meets with great success, 24—35.
Returns to Rome, triumphs, and assumes the surname of Africanus, 45.
Accepts the post of lieutenant-general under his brother, 37.1.
Receives his son from Antiochus, and rejects his offers, 34, 36.
Where he dies, and, according to his orders previously given, is buried, 53.

div1.head: P. Cornelius Nasica
div1.p: son of Cornelius, not yet of quaestorian age, is judged the best man in Rome, and sent to receive the Idaean Mother, 29.13.

div1.head: P. Cornelius Sulla
div1.p: The first that solemnized the Apollinarian games, 12, 19, 22.

div1.head: Ser. Cornelius
div1.p: Flamen Quirinalis, dies of the plague, 3.22.

div1.head: Cornus
div1.p: capital of Sardinia, taken by T. Manlius, 23.40.

div1.head: Cortona
div1.p: solicits peace with the Romans, a truce is granted, 9.37.

div1.head: Crito
div1.p: of Bercea, ambassador from Philip to Hannibal, 23.39.

div1.head: Croton
div1.p: Revolts to Hannibal after the battle of Cannae, 22.61.

div1.head: Crown of gold
div1.p: presented in the Capitol to Jupiter by the Latins, 2.22; 3.57. See 4.20; 7.38.

div1.head: Cumae
div1.p: Besieged by Hannibal, and defended by Gracchus, 23.36.

div1.head: P. Curatius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, accuses two military tribunes, 5.11.

div1.head: M. Curtius
div1.p: leaps into a gulf in the forum, 7.6.

div1.head: Damocritus
div1.p: Falls into the hands of the Romans, 36.24.
Disappointed in an attempt to escape, he kills himself, 37.46.

div1.head: Dardanians
div1.p: They are defeated by the Bastarnians, 41.19.

div1.head: Dasius Altinius
div1.p: of Arpi, a traitor, thrown into prison by the Romans, his family burned by Hannibal, 24.45.

div1.head: Debts
div1.p: very great at Rome; disturbances and secession in consequence, 2.23, 33.
Commissioners (mensarii) appointed to regulate matters respecting debts, 7.21.
A law passed against imprisoning debtors, 8.28.

div1.head: Decemvirs
div1.p: appointed to form a body of laws, 3.32.
They retain the power after their time had expired, 38.
Are compelled to abdicate the office, 54.
Two of them die in prison; the rest are banished, and their goods confiscated, 58

div1.head: Decemvirs
div1.p: commissioners of religious matters, half patrician, and half plebeian, 6.37, 42.

div1.head: P. Decius Mus
div1.p: rescues the legions from a desperate situation, 7.34, 35, 36.

div1.head: P. Decius Mus
div1.p: A second time, when he commands in Etruria, 41.
He devotes himself for the army, 28.

div1.head: Dedication
div1.p: of a temple must be performed by a consul or general, 9.45.

div1.head: Delium
div1.p: a temple of Apollo and asylum, 35.51.

div1.head: Demetrius
div1.p: His quarrel with Perseus, and its immediate consequences, 7—16, 21, 23.

div1.head: Deserters
div1.p: scourged, and thrown from the rock, 24.20.

div1.head: Devoting law
div1.p: One of the Aequans and Volscians, 4.26.
The principal elders in Rome devote themselves, on the approach of the Gauls, 5.41.
A consul, dictator, or praetor, may devote either himself or any soldier regularly enlisted, for the army, 8.10.

div1.head: Diana of Ephesus
div1.p: and her temple on the Aventine, 1.45.
A lectisternium in honour of her, 22.10.
Festival of three days at Syracuse, 25.23.

div1.head: Dictator
div1.p: An instance of an appeal by Fabius, 8.33.
Dictator nominated to drive the nail, 7.3; 8.18.
Dictator not allowed to use a horse without leave of the people, 23.14.
Warm disputes about the nomination of dictators, 4.56; 27.5.

div1.head: Sex. Digitius
div1.p: claims a mural crown, on the capture of New Carthage, 26.48.

div1.head: Dinomenes
div1.p: life-guard of Hieronymus, conspires against him, 24.7.

div1.head: Dionysius
div1.p: tyrant of Sicily, gets possession of the citadel of Croton, 24.3.

div1.head: M. Duillius
div1.p: His good conduct respecting the decemvirs, 3.52, 54.
He procures the passing of a law, allowing an appeal from the consuls, 54.
Opposes his colleagues, who wish to continue in office, 64.

div1.head: Duumvirs
div1.p: commissioners in religious affairs, keepers of the Sibylline books, 3.10; 5.13.

div1.head: Ecetrans
div1.p: peace granted to them, and part of their lands taken from them, 2.25.

div1.head: Echedemus
div1.p: employed by Philip as envoy to the Acarnanians, 33.16.

div1.head: Eclipse of
div1.p: the moon, foretold to the army by Sulpicius Gallus, 44.37.
Custom of making noise on it, 26.5.

div1.head: Edesco
div1.p: a celebrated Spanish general, joins Scipio, 27.17.

div1.head: Egerius
div1.p: son of Aruns, so named from his poverty, 1.34, 38.

div1.head: Gellius Egnatius
div1.p: Samnite general, advises war with the Romans, 10.18.
Invites the Umbrians to join him, and tempts the Gauls, 21.

div1.head: Elders
div1.p: Elders obliged to undertake the guard of the city, 5.10; 6.2, 6.

div1.head: Carthaginian Elders
div1.p: thirty form the principal council of state, 30.16.

div1.head: Eleans
div1.p: Machanidas resolves to attack them during the Olympic games, 28.7.

div1.head: Elephants
div1.p: Method of killing them invented by Hasdrubal, 27.49.

div1.head: Emporiae
div1.p: city in Spain, founded by Phocaeans, 21.60; 26.19; 28.42.

div1.head: Epicydes
div1.p: sent by Hannibal, with his brother Hippocrates, ambassador to Hieronymus, 24.6, 23.
Epicydes commands in the city when besieged by the Romans, 35.

div1.head: Etrurians
div1.p: Are displeased at the Veians for electing a king, 5.1.
Are routed, 4, 5. See 10, 18, 30. Meditate a revolt, 27.21.

div1.head: Evander
div1.p: Arcadian, introduces the use of letters in Italy, 1.5, 7.

div1.head: Cretan Evander
div1.p: Is put to death by him, 45.5.

div1.head: Eumenes
div1.p: king of Pergamus, joins the Romans against Antiochus, 36.42, 45.
Is obliged to go home to protect Pergamus, 37.18.
Advises Aemilius not to listen to overtures of peace, 19.
Assists in the total overthrow of Antiochus, 41, 42.
And is rewarded with a large addition of territory, 56.

He comes to Rome, and discovers the designs of Perseus, 42.6,11—13. Is assaulted near Delphi, 15. He and the Romans are worsted by Perseus, 59. Whom they afterwards defeat, and Eumenes becomes suspected by the Romans, 44.20.
He sends ambassadors to Rome with congratulations, 45.13.
Makes a truce with the Gauls, 34.

div1.head: Euphranor
div1.p: Macedonian general, relieves Meliboea from a siege, 44.13.

div1.head: Euthymidas
div1.p: head of a faction at Chalcis, 35.37, 38.

div1.head: Fabian family
div1.p: Undertake the war with the Veians, 48.
Are all cut off except one, 50.

div1.head: C. Fabius
div1.p: consul, wages an unsuccessful war with the Tarquinians, 7.12, 15.

div1.head: Caeso Fabius
div1.p: quaestor, accuses Sp. Cassius of treason, 2.41.
A second time consul, when his troops refuse to conquer, 43.
He and his brother renew the fight, 46.
Is chosen consul a third time, 48.
Leads his family against the Veians, 49.

div1.head: C. Fabius Dorso
div1.p: during the siege of the Capitol, passes through the Gauls to perform sacrifice, and returns safe, 5.46.

div1.head: M. Fabius
div1.p: chief pontiff, dictates the form of words, in which the Roman elders devote themselves on the approach of the Gauls, 5.41.

div1.head: M. Fabius Ambustus
div1.p: whose daughter's envy of her sister occasioned the consulship to be opened to plebeians, consular tribune, 6.22.

div1.head: Fabius Ambustus
div1.p: consul, honoured with an ovation over the Hernicians, 7.11.
Argues in favour of his son against Papirius, 8.33.

div1.head: M. Fabius Buteo
div1.p: dictator, without a master of horse, created for the purpose of filling up the senate, 23.22.

div1.head: Fabius
div1.p: the only survivor of the disaster at Cremera, consul, 3.1.
A third time consul, he conquers the Volscians, and is made one of the decemvirs for forming laws, 36.
He is banished with his colleagues, 58.

div1.head: Fabius
div1.p: ambassador to the Gauls, kills one of their leaders, and is made consular tribune, 5.35, 36.
He, with his brother, is called to an account for his conduct towards the Gauls, and dies, 6.1.

div1.head: Fabius Maximus
div1.p: Fights the Samnites contrary to the order of the dictator, Papirius, and is successful, 30.
Again consul, he defeats the Etrurians, 35.
Though at enmity with Papirius, nominates him dictator, 38.
A third time consul, he overthrows the Samnites and Umbrians, 41.
Censor, he distributes the lowest rabble among the four city tribes, and thence gains the surname of Maximus, 46.
A fourth time consul, he overcomes the Samnites, 10.13, 14.
Is made consul a fifth time, 22.

div1.head: Fabius Maximus
div1.p: His cautious method of conducting the war, 11—17.
He sells his estate to ransom prisoners, 23.
Saves from total defeat his master of horse, who had fought Hannibal contrary to his judgment, 28, 29.
His advice to the consul Aemilius, 39.
Acts as lieutenant-general under his son, 44.
Is made consul a fifth time, 27.7.
Effects a reconciliation between the consuls Livius and Nero, 35.
Opposes Scipio's design of carrying the war into Africa, 28.40; 29.19.

div1.head: Q. Fabius
div1.p: Makes his father dismount on approaching him, 44.

div1.head: Fabius
div1.p: lieutenant-general, despatched to the senate by Livius, 28.9.

div1.head: Q. Fabius Pictor
div1.p: sent to consult the oracle at Delphi, 22.57.

div1.head: Fabraternians
div1.p: taken into protection by the Romans, 8.19.

div1.head: Faith
div1.p: solemnly worshippd, by order of Numa, 1.21.

div1.head: Falerians
div1.p: or Faliscians, assist the Veians and Fidenatians, 4.17.
Attack the Roman camp at Veii, 5.8, 13.
Are defeated by Camillus, their camp taken, and their city besieged, 19, 26.
The treacherous schoolmaster is punished, and the town surrenders, 27.

div1.head: Falernian lands
div1.p: as far as the river Vulturnus, divided among the commons of Rome, 8.11.

div1.head: Fasces
div1.p: do not attend both consuls in the city, 2.1.
Lowered, in compliment to the people, by Publicola, 7.

div1.head: Fecenia
div1.p: Hispala, a courtesan, discovers the practices of the Bacchanalians, 39.9, 11, 13.

div1.head: Feronia
div1.p: Her temple at Capena struck by lightning, 33.26.

div1.head: Fidenatians
div1.p: make war on the Romans, and are conquered, 1.14.

div1.head: Flamen of Jupiter must not spend one night out of the city
C. Flaminius
div1.p: Goes privately to Ariminum, where he assumes the office, 63.
Is killed in the battle of Thrasimene, 22.4, 6.

div1.head: Cn. Flavius
div1.p: a notary, made curule aedile, and opposes the patricians; publishes the civil law, and exhibits the calendar in tablets hung round the forum, 9.46.

div1.head: M. Flavius
div1.p: makes a distribution of flesh meat, 8.22.

div1.head: Fleet
div1.p: launched in forty-five days after the timber was brought from the wood, 28.45.

div1.head: Forum
div1.p: Adorned with the gilded shields of the Samnites, 9.40.

div1.head: Frusinians
div1.p: mulcted a third part of their lands, 10.1.

div1.head: C. Fulcinius
div1.p: Roman ambassador, killed by order of Tolumnius, 4.17.

div1.head: Cn. Fulvius
div1.p: quaestor, delivered up to Hannibal by the Ligurians, 21.59.

div1.head: Cn. Fulvius Centumalus
div1.p: Is defeated by Hannibal at Herdonea, and slain, 27.1.

div1.head: M. Fulvius Nobilior
div1.p: Defeats the Celtiberians and their allies, taking their king prisoner, 35.7.
Wages war with success against the Aetolians, 38.4—12.
A triumph is decreed to him after some dispute, 39.5.

div1.head: Q. Fulvius Flaccus
div1.p: Follows Hannibal on his route to Rome, 8—10.
He is continued in command at Capua, 22.

div1.head: Q. Fulvius Flaccus
div1.p: Triumphs over the Celtiberians. and is chosen consul, 43.

Strips the temple of Juno Lacinia, xlii.
3. Hangs himself, 28.

div1.head: Fundae
div1.p: its inhabitants made Roman citizens without right of suffrage, 8.14.

div1.head: Furius and Fusius
div1.p: lieutenant-general, brother of the consul Sp. Furius, killed by the Aequans, 3.5.

div1.head: L. Furius and Camillus
div1.p: dictator, restores the consulship to the patricians, and is elected consul, 7.24.

div1.head: L. Furius and Medullinus
div1.p: a person or persons of this name held the following offices, but the accounts are obscure: Consular tribune, 4.25,35. Again, 44. Consul, 51. Again, 54. Consular tribune, 57. Again, 61. A third time, 5.14.

div1.head: L. Furius and Purpureo
div1.p: Attends a general assembly of the Aetolians, 31.29.

div1.head: M. Furius and Camillus
div1.p: A third time, he ravages Campania, 14.
Defeats the Faliscians, and takes Veii, 25.
Opposes the design of removing to Veii, and is made consular tribune a fourth time, 26.
Sends back to the Falerians their children, and he traitor who brought them to his camp, 27.
Interrex, he is accused by Apuleius; goes into exile, and is fined, 32.
Utterly vanquishes the Gauls, and triumphs, 49.
Dictator a third time, he takes the Volscian camp, 6.1.
His moderation towards his colleague, and success in war, 23, 25.
A fifth, he triumphs over the Gauls, 42.

div1.head: M. Furius
div1.p: defends M. Aurelius against charges made by Philip, 30.42.

div1.head: P. Furius Philus
div1.p: Is accused by Metellus, plebeian tribune, and dies, 43.

div1.head: Sp. Furius
div1.p: consul, worsted by the Aequans, and surrounded in his camp, 3.4.

div1.head: Gabii
div1.p: taken by the treachery of Sex. Tarquinius, 1.53, 54; 24.10; 26.9.

div1.head: Gallogrecians
div1.p: They are subdued by Cn. Manlius Vulso, 23.

div1.head: Games
div1.p: Roman, or great, exhibited by Romulus, 1.9.
Established by Tarquinius Priscus, to be performed annually, 35.

div1.head: Funeral Games
div1.p: remarkable, exhibited by the sons of Aemilius Lepidus, 23.30.

div1.head: Ganymedes
div1.p: governor of Aenus, for Ptolemy, betrays it to Philip, 31.16.

div1.head: Gates of a Roman camp
div1.p: Decuman, or quaestorian, in the rear, 3.5; 10.32.

div1.head: Gates of the city of Rome
Cn. Gavillius
div1.p: and L., cause a great alarm at Rome, 41.5.

div1.head: Gauls
div1.p: enticed by the delicious fruits and wines, had come into Italy 200 years before the taking of Rome, 5.17.
March to Rome, and gain a victory at the Allia, 37, 38.
Advance within three miles of Rome, 7.9.
On their champion being slain by Manlius, retire in dismay, 9, 11.
The Gauls, for a large sum of money, make peace with the Etrurians, 10.10.
They, in conjunction with the Etrurians, Samnites, and Umbrians, are defeated by the Romans, 27, 29.
The Senones cut off a Roman legion, 26.
Submit to the Roman consul, and retire, 54.

div1.head: M. Geganius Macerinus
div1.p: consul, quashes the combinations of the plebeian tribunes against the patricians, 3.65.
Is made consul a second time, 4.8.
He overthrows the Volscians, sends them under the yoke, and triumphs, 10.

div1.head: Gelo
div1.p: son of Hiero, favouring the Carthaginians, is carried off by a sudden death, 23.30.

div1.head: Geminius Metius
div1.p: Etrurian, his single combat with T. Manlius, 8.7.

div1.head: Gentius
div1.p: Ambassadors sent to him from Rome, 42.26.
He imprisons the ambassadors, and takes part with Perseus, 44.27.
Murders his brother, and his two friends, 30.
Surrenders himself to the Roman praetor, Anicius, 31.
Is led in triumph, with his queen, children, and brother, 45.43.

div1.head: Genucius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, killed in his own house, 2.54.

div1.head: Cn. Genucius
div1.p: A second time, when he falls in battle, 18.

div1.head: Cn. Genucius
div1.p: one of the first plebeian augurs, 10.9.

div1.head: L. Genucius
div1.p: Is slain in battle with the Hernicians, 6.

div1.head: L. Genucius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, proposes a law against usury, 7.42.

div1.head: T. Genucius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, proposes an Agrarian law, and accuses T. Menenius, 2.52.
Makes a heavy charge on the consuls of the preceding year, and is put to death, 54.

div1.head: Gisgo
div1.p: arguing against peace, is treated roughly by Hannibal, 30.37.

div1.head: Gods
div1.p: The custom of calling them out from the town of an enemy, and the ceremonies used in removing their images, 5.21, 22.

div1.head: Gold
div1.p: pounds' weight stipulated as the ransom of the Roman people, 5.48.
Retaken, and placed under the throne of Jupiter, 50.

div1.head: Gown
div1.p: bordered with purple, praetexta, borrowed from the Etrurians, 1.8.

div1.head: Gradivus
div1.p: His priests Salii instituted by Numa, 1.20.

div1.head: Grecian fleet
div1.p: Another, under Cleonymus, a Spartan, is compelled to retire by the Patavians, 10.2.

div1.head: Grecian states
div1.p: declared free by T. Quintius, at the Isthmian games, 33.32.

div1.head: Gulussa
div1.p: son of Masinissa, pleads before the senate in favour of his father, 42.24.

div1.head: Haliartus
div1.p: Is taken by the praetor Lucretius, 63.

div1.head: Halicarnassians
div1.p: obliged to the Rhodians for their liberty, 33.20.

div1.head: Hamae
div1.p: near Cumae, the camp of the Campanians, is surprised there by Gracchus, 23.35.

div1.head: Hamilcar
div1.p: forming plans for a war against the Romans, dies, 21.1, 2, 5.
This happened at a place in Spain called Highfort, 24.41.
acting in concert with the Insubrian Gauls, is killed in battle at Cremona, 31.21.
son of Bomilcar, defeated by the Scipios, 23.49.
son of Gisgo, given up to the Romans, with the isle of Melita, 21.51.
Carthaginian general, made prisoner by Cn. Cornelius, 32.30.

div1.head: Hannibal
div1.p: about nine years old, swears perpetual enmity to the Romans, 21.1.
Is appointed general in the place of Hasdrubal, 3.
Passes the Iberus and Pyrenaean mountains, 23.
He defeats the Romans at Ticinus, 46.
Escapes out of a defile by the stratagem of tying faggots to the horns of oxen, 16.
Worsts Minucius, who is saved by Fabius, 29.
Pretends flight, but his scheme is detected, 42.
Distressed and perplexed, he removes to Canne, 43.
There overthrows the Romans with great slaughter, 49.
Is defeated at Nola by Marcellus, 16.
His men enervated by the luxury of Capua, 18.
Are long resisted by a small body of Praenestines, at Casilinum, which at last surrenders, 19.
He gains possession of Tarentum by treachery, 25.8—10.
Defeats Cn. Fulvius, praetor, at Herdonia, 21.
Resolves to lay siege to Rome, 26.7.
Encamps within three mile of that city, 10.
Failing in his attempt, he retires, 11.
Vanquishes Cn. Fulvius, proconsul, at Herdonea, 27.1.
He surrounds Marcellus, who is slain, 27.
After the death of Hasdrubal, he retires into Bruttium, 51.
Worsted by Scipio, he retires from Locri, 29.7.
Is conquered at Zama, and flies to Adrumetum, 35.
Is kindly received by Antiochus, at Ephesus, 33.49.
Advises; Antiochus to attack the Romans in Italy, 34.60.
Is restored to his good opinion, 36.6, 15, 41.
Is defeated at sea by the Rhodians, 37.24.
Is compelled by the Romans to leave the court of Antiochus, 45.
Having found refuge with Prusias, but being still persecuted by the Romans, he swallows poison, 39.51.

div1.head: Hanno
div1.p: head of the faction which opposed the Barcine, insists that Hannibal ought not to be sent into Spain, 21.3.
but to be given up to the Romans, 9.
After the battle of Cannae, he recommends making proposals of peace to the Romans, 23.13.

div1.head: Hanno
div1.p: son of Bomilcar, distinguishes himself in the passage of the Rhone, 21.27, 28.
Defeated and taken in Spain by Cn. Scipio, 21.60.
Driven out of Lucania by Sempronius Longus, 23.17.
Persuades the Grecian cities in Bruttium to join him, 24.1.
Fights a desperate battle with Gracchus, 14, 15.
Succeeds Hasdrubal Barcas as commander in Spain, 28.1.
Is made prisoner by the Romans, 2.

div1.head: Hanno
div1.p: an officer under Mago, is routed by L. Marcius, 28.30.

div1.head: Hanno
div1.p: general of cavalry, falls in battle, 29.29, 35.

div1.head: Hanno
div1.p: son of Hamilcar, defeated and slain by Masinissa, 29.34.

div1.head: Harmonia
div1.p: daughter of Gelon, put to death, 24.24, 25.

div1.head: Harpalus
div1.p: ambassador from Perseus, gives offence to the senate, 42.14.

div1.head: Hasdrubal
div1.p: son-in-law and successor of Hamilcar, killed by a savage, 21.2.

div1.head: Hasdrubal brother
div1.p: of Hannibal, is left commander in Spain, 21.22.
Cuts off the two Roman generals, with the greatest part of their men, 25.32.
Passes into Gaul, and over the Alps, 36, 39.
Is vanquished at the Metaurus, and slain, 48, 49.
His head is thrown into Hannibal's camp, 51.

div1.head: Hasdrubal
div1.p: son of Gisgo, commands in Spain, 24.41.
He and Scipio dine together in the house of Syphax, 18.
He gives his daughter in marriage to Syphax, 29.23.
He and Syphax are defeated by Scipio, 30.5, 6.

div1.head: Hasdrubal Haedus
div1.p: advises the Carthaginians to conclude a peace, 30.42.

div1.head: Heraea
div1.p: The direction of the Heraean, or Junonian games, is conferred on Philip, 27.30.

div1.head: Hercules
div1.p: A lectisternium, or banquet, in honour of him, 5.13.

div1.head: Herdonea
div1.p: Is taken by Hannibal, and the inhabitants are expelled, 27.1.

div1.head: Herennius Bassus
div1.p: and Herius Pettius Nolans, confer with Hanno, 23.43.

div1.head: Samnite Herennius Pontius
div1.p: His opposite opinions respecting the Romans at Caudium, 3.

div1.head: T. Herminius
div1.p: assists Horatius Cocles in defending the bridge, 2.10.

div1.head: Hernicians
div1.p: Their lands are wasted by Aequans and Volscians, 3.6.
They are subdued by C. Plautius, 15.

div1.head: Herodicus
div1.p: Thessalian, killed by Philip, and his family persecuted, 40.4.

div1.head: Hiero
div1.p: king of Syracuse, promises corn and clothing to the Roman legions, 21.50.
After the defeat at Trasimenus, he sends ample supplies to the Romans, and a golden image of victory, 22.37.

div1.head: Hieronymus
div1.p: Hiero's grandson and successor, his character, and a conspiracy formed against him, 24.4, 5.
He sneers at the Roman ambassador, 6.

div1.head: Himilco
div1.p: Brings supplies to Syracuse, and dies of the plague, 25.26.

div1.head: Hippocrates
div1.p: in conjunction with the Carthaginians, carries on war against Marcellus, 24.35.
Brings supplies to Syracuse, and dies, 25.26.

div1.head: Hirpinians
div1.p: Their towns are taken by the Romans, 17.

div1.head: Horatius Cocles maintains the Sublician bridge
div1.p: leaps into the river, and escapes, 2.10.

div1.head: C. Horatius Cocles maintains the Sublician bridge
C. Horatius maintains the Sublician bridge Pulvillus
L. Horatius maintains the bridge Pulvillus Barbatus
div1.p: Drives Ap. Claudius out of the forum, 49.
Defeats the Sabines, and triumphs without leave of the senate, 61, 63. See 4.6.

div1.head: M. Horatius maintains the bridge Barbatus Pulvillus
M. Horatius maintains the bridge Barbatus
P. Horatius maintains the bridge
div1.p: labours to save his son from the punishment incurred by killing his sister, 1.26.

div1.head: Horses
div1.p: Taken from some by the censors, 24.18; 27.11.

div1.head: Hostages of the Tarentines
div1.p: attempting an escape, are seized, and put to death, 25.7.

div1.head: Hostages of
div1.p: the Spanish states are restored to their friends by Scipio, 26.49.

div1.head: Hostilius Cato
div1.p: two of this name, A. and C., 27.35.

div1.head: L. Hostilius Mancinus
div1.p: sent by Minucius with four hundred horsemen to procure intelligence, is cut off by the Carthaginians, 22.15.

div1.head: Hostus Hostilius
div1.p: distinguishes himself in battle against the Sabines, and falls, 1.12.

div1.head: Iberus river
div1.p: the boundary between the Romans and Carthaginians in Spain, 21.2, 5; 26.17.

div1.head: L. Icilius
div1.p: Is made plebeian tribune on the Aventine, 54.

div1.head: Sp. Icilius
div1.p: three of that name plebeian tribunes in one year, 4.54.

div1.head: Idaean Mother brought to Rome from Pessinus in Asia
Ilergetians
div1.p: Their country wasted by Cn. Scipio, 62.
They implore aid from the Romans, 34.11.

div1.head: Illiturgis
div1.p: is besieged by the Carthaginians, and relieved by the Romans, 23.49.
Is taken by Scipio, and burnt, 20, 25.

div1.head: Illyrians
div1.p: their designs, in favour of Philip, are discovered to the Romans, 42.26.

div1.head: Indibilis
div1.p: His family kindly treated by Scipio, 26.49.
Submits to Scipio, and is pardoned, 34.
Revolts, and is killed in battle, 29.2, 3.

div1.head: Ingaunian Ligurians
div1.p: A treaty between them and the Romans, 31.2.

div1.head: Insubrian Gauls
div1.p: a canton of the Aeduans, found Mediolanum, 5.34.

div1.head: Interamna
div1.p: In vain attempted by the Samnites, 10.36.
Is compelled to contribute more than usual, 29.15.

div1.head: Istrians
div1.p: The Romans at war with them, 41.1, 11.

div1.head: Jamphorina
div1.p: capital city of Maedica, surrendered to the Romans, 26.25.

div1.head: Janus
div1.p: his temple shut twice after the reign of Numa, 1.19.

div1.head: Jassus
div1.p: The Romans raise the siege of it at the request of the Rhodians, 37.17.

div1.head: Jubellius Taurea
div1.p: Campanian, his encounter with Cl. Asellus, 23.8, 47.

div1.head: C. Julius Julus
div1.p: Is deputed by the senate to the seceders on the Aventine, 50.

div1.head: C. Julius Mento
div1.p: consul, disputes with his colleague and the senate, 4.26.

div1.head: D. Junius Scaeva
div1.p: commander at the mouth of the Vulturnus, 25.22.

div1.head: Brutus Junius
div1.p: L., is sent to Delphi, with the sons of Tarquinius, 1.56.
Takes the lead in expelling the Tarquins, 59.
Puts his own sons to death for a conspiracy, 2.2.
Falls in fight, together with Aruns his antagonist, 6.

div1.head: M. Junius Pera
div1.p: dictator, after the battle of Cannae, 22.57; 23.14.

div1.head: M. Junius
div1.p: deputed to the senate by the prisoners in the hands of Hannibal, 22.59.

div1.head: M. Junius Silanus
div1.p: He gains a victory over Mago and Hanno, 28.2.

div1.head: M. Junius Brutus
div1.p: Commissioner to settle the affairs of Asia, 37.55.

div1.head: P. Junius Brutus
div1.p: plebeian tribune, supports the Oppian law, 34.1.

div1.head: P. Junius
div1.p: Leads an army against the Etrurians, 37.2.

div1.head: Q. Junius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, proposes to revenge the death of Maaelius, 4.16.

div1.head: Juno
div1.p: An offering made to her by Camillus, 6.4.
A temple dedicated to her by M. Aemilius, 40.52.

div1.head: Knights
div1.p: The number doubled by Serv. Tullius, 43.
There are three hundred in each legion, 8.8.
They are furnished with horses by the public, 1.43, 45.
They serve on their own horses, and pay is assigned to them, 5.7.
The censors punish several for misconduct, by depriving them of their horses, 24.18; 27.11; 29.37.
Six hundred are given as hostages to the Samnites, 9.5.

div1.head: Labici
div1.p: It is taken by the Romans, who settle a colony there, 4.47, 49.

div1.head: Lacedaemon
div1.p: robbed by Nabis and his wife, 32.40.
Visited by P. Aemilius, 45.28. See Sparta.

div1.head: Lacedaemonians
div1.p: or Laconians, under Cleonymus, infest the coast of Italy, 10.2.
War is declared against them by the Romans, 34.22.
They are subdued by T. Quintius, 26.40.
Are given in charge to the Achaeans, 35.13.
Their towns on the coast are attacked by Nabis, 22.
They are delivered from the tyranny of Nabis, who is assassinated by Aetolians, and they join the Achaean league, 36.

div1.head: Lacetanians
div1.p: They attack the allies of the Romans, 28.24.
M. Silanus is sent against them, 26. See 33.34.

div1.head: C. Laelius
div1.p: is appointed commander of the fleet by Scipio, 26.42.

Sent to Africa, 29.1,4, 6. Goes with Scipio into Africa, 25. He and Masinissa pursue and defeat Syphax, 30.9, 11,
13, 17.

div1.head: M. Laetorius
div1.p: chief centurion, is appointed to dedicate a temple of Mercury, 2.27.

div1.head: Lampsacus
div1.p: Is admitted into alliance with Rome, 43.6.

div1.head: Larissa
div1.p: a council of the Thessalians held there, 36.8.

div1.head: Lars
div1.p: or Lartes. See Porsenna and Tolumnius.

div1.head: Sp. Lartius
div1.p: assists Horatius in defence of the bridge, 2.10.

div1.head: Latins are
div1.p: conquered by Ancus Marcius, and many removed to Rome, 1.32, 33.
They suffer a severe overthrow at the lake Regillus, 2.19, 20.
They assist the Romans against the Aequans and Volscians, 3.7.
Require a consul, and half the senate of Rome, to be chosen out of Latium, 5.
The Romans declare war, and entirely subdue them, 6—14.

div1.head: Latinus
div1.p: king, forms an alliance and affinity with Aeneas, 1.1.

div1.head: Lavinia
div1.p: married to Aeneas, and Lavinium built, 1.1.

div1.head: Laurentians
div1.p: the treaty with them renewed annually, ten days after the Latin festival, 8.11.

div1.head: Lectisternium
div1.p: or banquet of the gods, the first at Rome, and the ceremonies used, 5.13; 7.2, 27; 8.24; 22.1, 10, &c.; one at Caere, 21.62.

div1.head: Leonatus
div1.p: commander of the chosen band of Perseus, 42.51.

div1.head: Leonides
div1.p: Lacedaemonian, commands the Grecian auxiliaries under Perseus, 42.51.

div1.head: Hieronymus Leontini
div1.p: The city is occupied by Hippocrates and Epicydes, 29.

div1.head: Leptis
div1.p: The dominion of it disputed by Masinissa and the Carthaginians, 34.62.

div1.head: Letus
div1.p: mount, where the Ligurians are defeated, 41.18.

div1.head: Leucas
div1.p: Is exempted from the government of the Acarnanians, 45.31.

div1.head: Levy of troops
div1.p: not made out of the whole people indiscriminately, 4.46.

div1.head: Levy of all kinds of men
Temple of Liberty
div1.p: Court in which the Tarentine hostages were kept, 25.7; 34.44.

div1.head: Licinius Macer
div1.p: who wrote a history of Rome. 4.7, 20, 23; 7.9; 10.9, &c.

div1.head: Licinius Calvus
div1.p: Stolo, C., plebeian, married to the daughter of Fab. Ambustus, is made plebeian tribune, 6.35.
Being plebeian tribune a tenth time, he effects the passing of his laws against the patricians, 6.42.
Is condemned on one of his own laws, 16.

div1.head: C. Licinius Crassus
div1.p: Proconsul and commissioner to settle the affairs of Macedonia, 45.17.

div1.head: P. Licinius Calvus
div1.p: The same post being offered to him again, he requests it may be conferred on his son, 18.

div1.head: P. Licinius Crassus
div1.p: He and his army suffer by sickness, 29.10.
He and the consul Sempronius defeat Hannibal, 36.

div1.head: P. Licinius
div1.p: chief pontiff, disputes with Fabius, flamen of Quirinus, 37.51.

div1.head: Ligurians
div1.p: Ambassadors sent to them from Rome, 22.33.
Ravage the country on the Po, 34.56.
Both consuls are sent against them, 38.42.
They surrender, and are removed from the mountains, 40.38, 41.
They and their effects are sold, 8.

div1.head: Sp. Ligustinus
div1.p: receives public thanks for encouraging the levies, 42.34.

div1.head: Litana
div1.p: wood, where the Gauls destroy a Roman army, 23.24.

div1.head: Livius
div1.p: poet, first who wrote comedy on a regular plot, 7.2.

div1.head: M. Livius Denter
div1.p: One of the first plebeian pontiffs, 9.
Dictates to Decius the form of devoting himself, 28.

div1.head: M. Livius
div1.p: Eight years after a severe sentence had been passed on him, he is brought back to Rome, and, against his will, made consul a second time, 27.34.
Censor; he acquires the surname Salinator, and maintains a shameful dispute with his colleague, 29.37.

div1.head: M. Livius
div1.p: Is obliged to retire into the citadel, 25.10, 11; 26.39.
A dispute about him in the senate, 27.25.

div1.head: T. Livius
div1.p: wrote in the reign of Augustus, 28.12. See 4.20.

div1.head: Locri
div1.p: Is put under the command of Pleminius, 8.
Its laws and liberty are restored by the senate, 21.

div1.head: Lucanians
div1.p: support the Samnites against Alexander of Epirus, 8.17. ,Make an alliance with the Romans, 25.
Several of their towns are taken by the Romans, 25.1.

div1.head: Luceria
div1.p: Lost, and recovered, and settled as a colony, 26.

div1.head: Lucretia
div1.p: Violated by Sex. Tarquinius, she kills herself, 58.

div1.head: C. Lucretius
div1.p: Is accused by the people of Chalcis, 43.7.

div1.head: L. Lucretius Flavus
div1.p: Consular tribune, he defeats the Volsinians, 32.

div1.head: L. Lucretius Tricipitinus
div1.p: consul, vanquishes the Volscians, and triumphs, 3.8, 10.

div1.head: Lucumo
div1.p: son of Demaratus, removes to Rome, where he is called Tarquinius, 1.34.

div1.head: Lucumo debauches
div1.p: the wife of Aruns of Clusium, 5.33.

div1.head: Cn. Lutatius
div1.p: Is restored to liberty sixteen years after, 30.19.

div1.head: Lycia
div1.p: The Lycians complain of the Rhodians, 41.6.

div1.head: Lycortas
div1.p: of Megalopolis, general of horse, father of Polybius the historian, 35.29.
Ambassador of the Achaeans to Rome, 38.32.

div1.head: Lycurgus
div1.p: lawgiver, his laws and institutions abolished, 38.34; 39.33, 36.

div1.head: Lysimachia
div1.p: having been sacked and burned by the Thracians, is rebuilt by Antiochus, 33.38, 40, 41; 34.58.

div1.head: Macedonia
div1.p: An obscure state before the reign of Philip, son of Amyntas, subsisted from its highest summit of grandeur under Alexander to Per seus, the last king, 150.

div1.head: Machanidas
div1.p: tyrant of Sparta, makes war on the Achaeans, 27.30; 28.5, 7.

div1.head: Sp. Maelius
div1.p: Is summoned to attend the dictator Cincinnatus, and slain by Servilius Ahala, 14.

div1.head: C. Maenius
div1.p: consul, triumphs over the Aricians and Lavinians, 8.13.
Dictator; he abdicates, is accused, and acquitted, 9.26, 34.

div1.head: L. Maenius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, regulates the interest of money, 7.16.

div1.head: M. Maenius
div1.p: proposes an Agrarian law, and obstructs the levies, 4.53.

div1.head: M. Maenius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, in the commotions excited by Manlius, submits to the direction of the senate, 6.19.

div1.head: M. Maenius
div1.p: military tribune, falls in a battie with Mago, 30.18.

div1.head: Magistrates
div1.p: Their election prevented during five years by the plebeian tribunes, 6.35.
Auspices are not observed at the election of plebeian magistrates, 6.41.

div1.head: Cn. Magius
div1.p: medixtuticus, or chief magistrate of Campania, 24.19.

div1.head: Decius Magius
div1.p: Capuan, maintains his fidelity to the Romans, and takes refuge in Egypt, 23.7, 10.

div1.head: Mago
div1.p: Carries to Carthage an account of Hannibal's successes, 23.12, 13.
Is sent into Spain, and defeated at Illiturgi, 32, 49.
In conjunction with Hasdrubal, Gisgo defeats P. Scipio, 25.32, 34.
Sails to Italy, and takes Genoa, 37, 46.

div1.head: Mago
div1.p: governor of New Carthage, surrenders to Scipio, 26.44, 46.

div1.head: Maharbal
div1.p: Pursues the Romans flying from Trasimenus, 22.6.
Advises Hannibal, after the battle of Cannae, to march directly to Rome, 51; 23.18.

div1.head: L. Mamilius
div1.p: dictator, of Tusculum, assists the Romans, 3.18, 29.

div1.head: Oct. Mamilius
div1.p: of Tusculum, descended from Ulysses and Circe, marries the daughter of Tarquinius the proud, 1.49.
Raises thirty states against the Romans, 18.

div1.head: Mandonius
div1.p: Brother of Indibilis, chief of the Ilergetians, 26.49.
He joins the Romans, and his wife and children are restored to him, 27.17.
He goes over to the enemy, 28.24.
Rebels, is taken and put to death, 29.3.

div1.head: Manes
div1.p: the rites proper for appeasing them are directed by the chief pontiff, 1.20.
Decius devotes himself to the gods, manes, and the earth, 8.9.

div1.head: Sex. Manilius
div1.p: a leader in the secession of the soldiers, 3.5.

div1.head: Aul. Manlius
div1.p: His accuser is murdered, and he is made decemvir, 3.33.

div1.head: Manlius
div1.p: Sent with a golden bason to Delphi, is taken by Liparaean pirates, and set at liberty, 28.

div1.head: A. Manlius
div1.p: consul when the first Punic war was terminated, 30.44.

div1.head: C. Manlius Vulso
div1.p: And after surmounting many difficulties, entirely subdues the Gauls, 27.
Is accused by his own lieutenant-generals, 38.45.
A triumph is decreed to him, 50; 39.6.

div1.head: L. Manlius Imperiosus
div1.p: His severity to his son, and the dutiful conduct of the latter, 4, 5.

div1.head: L. Manlius
div1.p: praetor, is defeated by the Boian Gauls, 21.17, 25.

div1.head: L. Manlius Acidinus
div1.p: Succeeds Scipio in the province of Spain, 28.38.
He is disappointed of an ovation by M. Porcius Laeca, 32.7.

div1.head: L. Manlius
div1.p: having assaulted Carthaginian ambassadors, is delivered up to them by the feciales, and sent to Carthage, 38.42.

div1.head: Manlius
div1.p: Is refused a triumph, and allowed an ovation, 39.29.

div1.head: M. Manlius Capitolinus
div1.p: He is brought to trial, condemned, and thrown from the Tarpeian rock, 20.

div1.head: T. Manlius
div1.p: son of L., an example of filial duty, 7.5.

He kills a Gaul in single combat, and is named Torquatus,
10. Is made dictator, 19. A second time, 26. Consul, 27. Again, 28. A third time, 8.3.

div1.head: T. Manlius Torquatus
div1.p: consul, dies, in consequence of a fall from his horse, 10.11.

div1.head: Manlius Torquatus
div1.p: votes against ransoming the prisoners taken at Cannae, 22.60.
Is sent governor of Sardinia, and subdues the island, 23.34, 40,41. Is a candidate for the post of chief pontiff, 25.5.

div1.head: Mannus
div1.p: a slave, discovers a plot of the Calavii to burn Rome, 26.27.

div1.head: C. Marcius
div1.p: signalizes himself in the taking of Corioli, and is surnamed Coriolanus, 2.33.
Is made general of the Volscians, 39.
Is prevailed on by his mother to retire from Rome, and dies, 40.

div1.head: Marcius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, prosecutes Q. Fabius for taking part in a fight against the Gauls, 6.1.

div1.head: C. Marcius Rutilus
div1.p: First plebeian dictator, he triumphs without leave of the senate, 27.

div1.head: L. Marcius
div1.p: chosen general by the soldiers on the death of the two Scipios in Spain, 25.37.
He takes the two camps of the enemy, 39.
He gives offence to the senate, 26.2.

div1.head: Q. Philippus
div1.p: His conference with Perseus, and insidious conduct, 42.40, 43.

div1.head: Marius Statilius detects a stratagem of Hannibal
Masgaba
div1.p: son of Masinissa, comes to Rome, 45.13, 14.

div1.head: Masinissa
div1.p: king of the Masylian Numidians, overthrows Syphax, 24.48, 49.
In alliance with the Carthaginians, he gives much trouble to P. Scipio, 25.34.
Confers, and forms a treaty with him, 28.16, 35.
His various turns of fortune, and expulsion from his kingdom, 29—32.
Marries Sophonisba, and being reproved by Scipio, sends her poison, 12, 14, 15.
Receives a large addition to his dominions, 44.
Presents sent to him from Rome, 31.11.
He sends a supply to the Romans, 19.
A dispute between him and the Carthaginians is pleaded at Rome, 42.23, 24.

div1.head: Massilians
div1.p: Inform the Romans of Hannibal's passing the Iberus, 21.25.

div1.head: Massiva
div1.p: nephew of Masinissa, is taken prisoner, and sent back to his uncle by Scipio, 27.19; 28.35.

div1.head: Master of horse
div1.p: Master of horse raised to an equality of power with the dictator, 22.25.
A dictator without a master of horse, 23.22, 23.

div1.head: Matrons
div1.p: Bring all their gold and ornaments to the treasury, 5.25.
Make a contribution towards satisfying the Gauls, 50.
A dispute between the patricians and plebeians, 10.23.
They dedicate a brazen statue to Juno on the Aventine, 21.62.
Receive the mother of the gods, 29.14.

div1.head: Mauri
div1.p: or Moors, auxiliaries to Hasdrubal in Spain, 21.22; 28.17.

div1.head: Medixtuticus
div1.p: title of the chief magistrate of Campania, 24.19; 26.6.

div1.head: Menenius
div1.p: He brings home the commons from the sacred mount, 32.

div1.head: Menippus
div1.p: envoy of Antiochus to the Aetolians, 35.32; 36.10.

div1.head: Mens
div1.p: Mind, a temple dedicated to her, 22.10; 23.31.

div1.head: Mensarii triumviri
div1.p: commissioners of the public accounts appointed for the liquidation of debts, 7.21; 23.21.

div1.head: Mericus
div1.p: a Spaniard, betrays the island, a part of Syracuse, to the Romans, 25.30.
Is rewarded with the freedom of Rome and a golden crown, 26.21.

div1.head: Messene
div1.p: Is besieged by the Achaeans, and united to them, 36.31.

div1.head: Metapontines
div1.p: after the battle of Cannae, revolt to Hannibal, 22.61; 25.15; 27.16.

div1.head: Q. Metellus
div1.p: Argues in favour of P. Scipio, 29.20.

div1.head: M. Metilius
div1.p: Proposes to give the master of horse equal authority with the dictator, 25.

div1.head: Vectius Mettius
div1.p: Volscian, distinguishes himself highly in battle, 4.28.

div1.head: Mezetulus
div1.p: Numidian, disputes the throne with Capusa, 29.29.

div1.head: Minii Celeres entertain Hannibal in Capua
Minors
div1.p: their money lent to the public, 24.18.

div1.head: L. Minucius
div1.p: He is relieved by the dictator Cincinnatus, and ordered to abdicate, 29.

div1.head: Minucius
div1.p: director of the market, discovers to the senate the designs of Maelius, 4.13.

div1.head: L. Minucius Myrtilus
div1.p: having ill-treated ambassadors of Carthage, is sent thither in custody, 38.42.

div1.head: M. Minucius Rufus
div1.p: Engages Hannibal, and is saved by Fabius from a total defeat, 28, 29.

div1.head: Misagenes
div1.p: Brings aid to the Romans against Perseus, 62.

div1.head: Money
div1.p: lent out of the treasury, secured by mortgages and bonds, 22.60.

div1.head: Money of
div1.p: widows and minors lent to the public, 24.18.

div1.head: Mother
div1.p: Her priests come out of Pessinus to meet the consul Manlius, 38.18.

div1.head: C. Mucius
div1.p: mistakes Porsenna's secretary for the king, and kills him, burns his right-hand, and is thence called Scaevola, 2.12,13.

div1.head: L. Mummius
div1.p: and Q., oppose the proposal of Petillius respecting Scipio Africanus, 38.54.

div1.head: Mutines
div1.p: having learned the art of war under Hannibal, is very troublesome to the Romans in Sicily, 25.40; 26.21.

div1.head: Nabis
div1.p: War is declared against him by the other states of Greece, 34.24.
He refuses the terms of peace offered by the Romans, 36.
Being besieged in Lacedaemon, he is forced to comply with them, 40.
The Acheans declare war against him, 35.25.

div1.head: Nadagara
div1.p: a conference there between Scipio and Hannibal, 30.29.

div1.head: Q. Naevius Crista
div1.p: praefect of allies, drives Philip out of his camp at Apollonta, 24.40.

div1.head: M. Naevius
div1.p: said by some to be the accuser of P. Scipio, 38.56.

div1.head: Q. Navius
div1.p: advises to mix footmen with the cavalry, 26.4.

div1.head: Sp. Nautius Rutilus
div1.p: commands the cohorts of the allies, 10.41.

div1.head: Neapolis
div1.p: Its ambassadors offer gold to the Romans, who accept the smallest bason, 22.32.
Its lands are ravaged by Hannibal, 24.13.

div1.head: Nemean games
div1.p: the direction of them given to Philip, 27.30, 31.

div1.head: Nepete
div1.p: is taken by the Etrurians, and recovered by the Romans, 6.9, 10.

div1.head: Neptune
div1.p: A lectisternium to obtain his favour, 5.13; 22.10.

div1.head: Nico
div1.p: forms a conspiracy, and betrays Tarentum to Hannibal, 25.8, 9.
Is killed in the capture of Tarentum, xxvii 16.

div1.head: Norba
div1.p: Maintains constant friendship with the Romans, 27.10.

div1.head: Nuceria
div1.p: The inhabitants are removed to Atella, 27.30.

div1.head: L. Numitorius
div1.p: chosen tribune in an assembly of the tribes, 2.58.

div1.head: Nymphius betrays Palaepolis to the Romans
Oesalces
div1.p: succeeds his brother Gala in the kingdom of Numidia, 29.29—31.

div1.head: Oeta
div1.p: mount, the highest part called Callidromos, 36.15, 22, 30; 37.5; 41.22.

div1.head: Ofilius Calavius
div1.p: a Campanian, his opinion of the silence of the Romans going home from Caudium, 9.6.

div1.head: Cn. Ogulnius
div1.p: and Q., plebeian tribunes, propose a law to open the priesthood to plebeians, 10.6.

div1.head: M. Ogulnius
div1.p: is sent into Etruria to purchase corn, 27.3.

div1.head: Onesimus
div1.p: a Macedonian, is received kindly by the Roman senate, admitted an ally, and presented with a house and land, 44.16.

div1.head: Onomastus
div1.p: by order of Philip, massacres the Maronites, 39.34; 40.8.

div1.head: L. Opiternius
div1.p: a Faliscian, a leader of the Bacchanals, 39.17.

div1.head: Oppia
div1.p: a vestal, condemned for a breach of chastity, 2.42.

div1.head: Oppia and Cluvia
div1.p: Campanian women, their liberty and goods are restored by the Romans, 26.33, 34.

div1.head: Oppius
div1.p: prefect of allies, is surprised by the Gauls, and slain, 31.2.

div1.head: Oppius
div1.p: proposer of the law forbidding women the use of golden ornaments, and a debate about that law, 31.1, 2, &c.

div1.head: L. Oppius Salinator
div1.p: commander of a fleet protecting Sicily, 35.23.

div1.head: Sp. Oppius Cornicen
div1.p: Is left in Rome with Ap. Claudius, 41.
Accused, and ordered into prison, he lays violent hands on himself, 58.

div1.head: Oricum
div1.p: is taken by Philip, and retaken by the Romans, 24.40; 26.25; 34.51, 52; 45.33.

div1.head: Oroandes
div1.p: a Cretan, robs Perseus of his treasure, 45.6.

div1.head: Orsua and Corbis determine
div1.p: in single combat, their dispute about the throne, 28.21.

div1.head: Orthobula
div1.p: wife of Proxenus, is condemned for poisoning her husband, 41.25.

div1.head: Oscan silver
div1.p: from Osca, now Huesca in Spain, 34.10.

div1.head: Ostia
div1.p: built at the mouth of the Tiber, by Ancus Marcius, 1.33; 22.11, 27; 23.38; 25.20; 27.22; 29.14.

div1.head: T. Otacilius
div1.p: Is sent as proprietor with a fleet to Sicily, 23.32.
Is disappointed in a near prospect of the consulship, by Q. Fabius, 24.7, 9; 25.31; 26.1, 22, 23.

div1.head: Ovile
div1.p: enclosure in the field of Mars, where the centuries gave their votes, 26.22.

div1.head: Ovius Paccius
div1.p: Samnite priest, directs the ceremonies in devoting the soldiers, 10.8.

div1.head: Pactius and Vibius
div1.p: brothers, men of eminence in Bruttium, apply to Q. Fabius, 27.15.

div1.head: Palm branches
div1.p: first given in token of victor at the Roman games, 10.47.

div1.head: Pantaleon
div1.p: Aetolian chief, protects Eumenes at Delphi, 42.15.

div1.head: Pantauchus
div1.p: ambassador, and intimate friend of Philip, 42.39; 44.23.

div1.head: L. Papirius Cursor
div1.p: He was censor when the city was taken, 9.34.

div1.head: L. Papirius Cursor
div1.p: Determines to punish Fabius, his master of horse, for fighting contrary to orders, 30, 34.
On the request of the people, forgives him, 35.
Is made consul a second time, 9.7.
He takes Luceria, and sends the Samnites under the yoke, 10.
Is made consul a fourth time, 22.
Dictator a second time; he triumphs over the Samnites, 40.

div1.head: M. Papirius
div1.p: one of the elders, slain by the Gauls on their entering Rome, 5.41.

div1.head: M. Papirius
div1.p: a commissioner for the liquidation of debts, 7.21.

div1.head: Papirius
div1.p: informs his uncle, the consul, of a defect in the auspices, 10.40.

div1.head: Patricians
div1.p: They insist that they only have the power of taking auspices, and consequently a right to magistracies, and the command of armies, 3.1; 6.41; 7.6.
Their contest with the plebeians about the consulship, 4.1.
They claim the offices of praetor and curule aedile, 6.42; 7.1.
They have the power of appointing an interrex, 6.41.
Are not eligible to plebeian magistracies, 4.25.
The law is repealed which forbade their intermarrying with plebeians, 4.6.

div1.head: T. Pedanius
div1.p: centurion, throws the standard among the enemy, and forces the Carthaginian camp, 25.14.

div1.head: Pedum
div1.p: By Camillus, and the inhabitants made citizens of Rome, 8.13.

div1.head: Perseus
div1.p: Quarrels with his brother Demetrius, 40.6–16. His forgery of letters detected, 54, 55. He gets possession of the kingdom, 57, 58. Prepares for war against the Romans, 41.22, 23.

Is accused at Rome by Eumenes, 42.11–13. Employs assassins to murder Eumenes, 15, 16; and Rammius of Brundusium to poison the Roman ambassadors, 17. Confers with Q. Marcius, 39–43. Collects a very large army, 51. Is worsted by the Romans, 59, 66. Gains advantages in Thrace and Illyria, 43.18–23. Is utterly defeated at Pydna by Aemilius Paullus, 44.42.
where he and his children are taken, 45.6, 7.

div1.head: Pharnaces
div1.p: king of Pontus, sends ambassadors to Rome, 40.20.

div1.head: Phaselis
div1.p: The fleet of Antiochus, commanded by Hannibal and Apollonius, is defeated there, 24.

div1.head: Philip
div1.p: Commences hostilities by taking Oricum, and is obliged to fly from Apollonia, 24.40.
Makes several incursions on the Thessalians and others, xxvi 25; 27.30; 28.7.
Concludes a peace with the Romans and Aetolians, 39.12.
Demands the Macedonian prisoners, who had served under Hannibal, and is refused by the senate, 30.42.
Makes a fruitless attempt on Athens, 24.
Holds a conference with the consul Quintius, 32.10.
Is defeated, and flies to Thessaly, 12.
At another conference he obtains a truce, 36.
but his application to the senate is rejected, 37.
He makes an alliance with Nabis, 38.
He is utterly defeated by Quintius, 33.7, 9.
He assists the Romans against Antiochus, 36.13.
Is offended at the behaviour of the Romans, 39.23, 29.
His cruelty to Herodicus and his family, 40.4.

His sons quarrel,
5–16. He employs Didas to poison Demetrius, 24. Discovers the villany of Perseus, and resolves to leave the crown to Antigonus, but dies, 54, 55.

div1.head: Philip
div1.p: Is sneered at by king Philip, 14.

div1.head: Philodemus
div1.p: betrays mount Euryalus to the Romans, 25.25.

div1.head: Philopoemen
div1.p: Defeated in a sea-fight by Nabis, 26.
His method of acquiring skill in war, 28.
Surprises and vanquishes Nabis on land, 27, 29.
Is taken by the Messenians, and poisoned, 39.50.

div1.head: L. Pinarius
div1.p: governor of Enna, suppresses an insurrection, 24.37, 39.

div1.head: Pisistratidae
div1.p: Hippias and Hipparchus, sons of Pisistratus, 31.44.

div1.head: Pisistratus
div1.p: a Boeotian of eminence, put to death for the murder of Brachyllas, 33.28.

div1.head: Placentia
div1.p: The Roman troops take refuge there, 57, 59.
It is sacked by Gauls and Ligurians, 31.10.

div1.head: Plator
div1.p: Macedonian, governor of Oreum, gives it up to the Romans, 28.6, 7.

div1.head: Plator
div1.p: brother of Gentius, murdered by him, 44.30.

div1.head: Q. Pleminius
div1.p: propraetor, takes one of the citadels of Locri, 29.6.
Is appointed by Scipio governor of the city, displays great cruelty and avarice, and robs the temple of Proserpine, 8.
Is sent to Rome in chains, 21.
and put to death for a plot to burn the city, 34.44.

div1.head: Polyaratus
div1.p: a man of power in Rhodes, 44.23, 29; 45.22.

div1.head: Polyaenus
div1.p: of Syracuse, his free and moderate address to his countrymen, 24.22.

div1.head: Polyxenidas
div1.p: a Rhodian, commander of Antiochus's fleet, defeated by the Romans, 36.45.
Imposes on the Rhodian commander, defeats and kills him, 37.10, 11.
Is defeated by the Romans and Rhodians, 30.

div1.head: Pomponius
div1.p: an infamous farmer of the revenues, 3.

div1.head: Man. Pomponius Matho
div1.p: master of horse, abdicates, because his appointment proved to be irregular, 22.33.

div1.head: M. Pomponius
div1.p: deputed to carry an offering to Delphi, 28.45.

div1.head: M. Pomponius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, protests against a war with Rhodes, 45.21.

div1.head: M. Pomponius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, accuses L. Manlius, whose son deters him from the prosecution, 7.45.

div1.head: Pontiff
div1.p: chief, created by Numa, his duties and privileges, 1.20; 4.44.

div1.head: Ti. Pontificius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, proposer of the Agrarian law, 2.44.

div1.head: Pontius Cominius
div1.p: swimming down the Tiber, conveys intelligence from Camillus to the besieged in the Capitol, 5.46.

div1.head: C. Pontius
div1.p: Samnite general, shuts up the Roman army in the defiles of Caudium, and sends them under the yoke, 9.1–15.

div1.head: M. Porcius Cato
div1.p: Pleads in support of the Oppian law, 34.2.
And effectually subdues all the country as far as the Iberus, 17.
Shows himself a bitter enemy to Scipio Africanus, 38.54.

div1.head: Porsenna
div1.p: Lar, or Lartes, king of Clusium, entertains the Tarquins, and makes war on the Romans, 2.9.
Restores the hostages, and concludes a treaty of friendship with the Romans, 15.

div1.head: Postumia
div1.p: a vestal, rebuked for too much attention to dress, 4.44.

div1.head: A. Postumius
div1.p: dictator, vanquishes the Latins at Regillus, and triumphs, 2.19, 20.

div1.head: A. Postumius Albus
div1.p: Ambassador to the Aequans, is affronted by their general, 25.

div1.head: A. Postumius Tibertus
div1.p: Dictator; defeats the Aequans and Volscians, 26, 29.

div1.head: L. Postumius Megellus
div1.p: Triumphs over Etruria, in opposition to the senate and people, 37.

div1.head: L. Postumius
div1.p: consul elect, cut off with his army in the wood Litina, 23.24.

div1.head: M. Postumius Purgensis
div1.p: a contractor for supplying the armies, outlawed, and his property confiscated, for fraudulent practices, 25.3, 4.

div1.head: Sp. Postumius
div1.p: Is sent under the yoke at Caudium, 6.

div1.head: Potitian family
div1.p: Delegate the office to slaves, and the family becomes extinct, 9.29.

div1.head: Praenestines revolt
div1.p: Are conquered, and the statue of Imperial Jupiter is removed to Rome, 28.
They aid the Pedans, and are punished, 8.12, 14.

div1.head: Praetor
div1.p: chosen out of the patricians to administer justice in the city, 6.42; 7.1.
Was elected under the same auspices, and considered as a colleague of the consuls, 3.55; 8.32.

div1.head: Praxo
div1.p: a woman of distinction at Delphi, confidant of Perseus, 42.15, 17.

div1.head: Priests
div1.p: chosen by Numa out of the patricians, 1.20.

div1.head: Prince or chief of the senate
div1.p: the mode of choosing him altered, 27.11.

div1.head: Privernum
div1.p: the inhabitants ravage the Roman territory, 7.15.
Are defeated, and their city taken, by C. Marcius, 16.
Renew the war, are conquered, and two parts of their lands taken from them, 8.1.
Again commence hostilities, are conquered, and their senate banished beyond the Tiber, 19, 20.
Undaunted reply of one of their ambassadors, 21.

div1.head: Proconsul
div1.p: The first who was continued in command on the expiration of his consulate, Publius Philo, 8.26.
Proconsuls had no authority in the city, 26.9.
