div1.head: Proculus Virginius
div1.p: consul, his contest with his colleague about the Agrarian law, 2.41.

div1.head: Proserpine
div1.p: Her temple at Locri robbed by Pleminius, 29.7.

div1.head: Prusias
div1.p: king of Bithynia, solicited by Antiochus to join him in war against the Romans, is prevented by a letter from Scipio Africanus, 37.25.
After giving refuge to Hannibal, he consents to surrender him to T. Quintius, 39.51.
Proposes to mediate between the Romans and Perseus, 44.14.
Comes to Rome, and behaves with abject meanness, 45.44.

div1.head: Prytanis
div1.p: the title of the chief magistrate of Rhodes, 42.45.

div1.head: Ptolemy Philopater
div1.p: king of Egypt, his statue affords refuge to Magius the Capuan, 23.10.
He renews a treaty of friendship with the Romans, 27.4.
Offers to repress the inroads of Philip, 31.9.

div1.head: Ptolemy and
div1.p: Cleopatra, king and queen of Egypt, offer aid to the Romans against Antiochus, 37.3.
The elder Ptolemy is reconciled to his brother and sister, and received in Alexandria, 45.11.
They are saved from the attempts of Antiochus by Roman ambassadors, 12.

div1.head: Publicans
div1.p: farmers of the revenue, furnish supplies to the troops at their own expense, on being promised payment when money should come into the treasury, 23.48, 49.
Fraudulent practices and turbulent behaviour of some of them, 25.3, 4.

div1.head: C. Publicius Bibulus
div1.p: plebeian tribune, his charges against Marcellus and the patricians, 27.21.

div1.head: Q. Publilius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, during the dissensions excited by Manlius, supports the cause of the senate, 6.19.
and commences a prosecution against Manlius, 20.

div1.head: Q. Publilius Philo
div1.p: consul, defeats the Latins, is nominated dictator, procures laws to be passed in favour of the commons, 8.12.
He is the first plebeian praetor, 15.
He is the first person continued in command on the expiration of his consulate, and the first that triumphed when out of office, 26.

div1.head: Volero Publilius
div1.p: a plebeian, refuses to enlist in the army, and appeals to the tribunes and to the people, 2.55.
Proposes a law, that plebeian magistrates should be elected in assemblies of the tribes; is re-elected tribune, ibid.

div1.head: Cn. Pupius
div1.p: a commissioner to build a temple of Concord, 22.33.

div1.head: P. Pupius
div1.p: one of the first plebeian quaestors, 4.54.

div1.head: Pyra
div1.p: on mount Oeta, the place were Hercules was burned, 36.30.

div1.head: Pyrrhias
div1.p: praetor of Aetolia, defeated by Philip, 27.30.

div1.head: Pyrrhus
div1.p: king of Epirus, his kind treatment of Roman prisoners, 22.59.
He was warned by the Romans to guard against poison, 39.51.
His dishonourable death a punishment for robbing the temple of Proserpine, 29.17.

div1.head: Pyrrhus's camp
div1.p: name of a place in Macedonia, 32.13; 35.27.

div1.head: Pythagoras
div1.p: the Samian philosopher, posterior to Numa, 1.18.
Some supposed that Numa's books were written by him, 40.29.

div1.head: Pythagoras
div1.p: son-in-law of Nabis, governor of Sparta, 34.25.

div1.head: Pythian Apollo
div1.p: his answer brought by Fabius Pictor the historian, 23.11.

div1.head: Pytho
div1.p: Macedonian, governor of Cassandrea, repulses the Romans, 44.12.

div1.head: Quadrants
div1.p: contributed by the people to bury Valerius, 3.18.

div1.head: Quadrireme
div1.p: galley of four banks of oars, 30.25.

div1.head: Quaestorium
div1.p: part of a camp taken by the Samnites, 10.32.

div1.head: Quinquatrus
div1.p: feast of Minerva, lasting five days, 26.27; 44.20.

div1.head: Quintilis
div1.p: month, the nones appointed for the Apollinarian games, xxvii 23. Calling magistrates into office, 5.32.

div1.head: Cn. Quintilius
div1.p: dictator, to drive a nail in the Capitol, 8.18.

div1.head: Caeso Quintius
div1.p: Is falsely charged with murder, is the first that gives bail to the people, goes into exile, 13.

div1.head: Caeso Quintius Flamininus
div1.p: commissioner to build a temple of Concord, 22.33.

div1.head: D. Quintius
div1.p: of obscure birth, remarkable for bravery and conduct, commander of a Roman fleet, is killed in a sea-fight with the Tarentines, 26.39.

div1.head: L. Quintius Cincinnatus
div1.p: supplicates the people in favour of his son Caeso, 3.12.
Is called from the plough to the dictatorship, 26.
Surrounds and vanquishes the Aequans, and sends them under the yoke, 27, 28.
Is presented by his army with a golden crown, and triumphs, 29.
A candidate for the decemvirate, fails, 35.
Executes the business of censor with moderation, 4.6.

div1.head: L. Quintius Crispinus
div1.p: Triumphs over the Celtiberians and Lusitanians, 39.42.

div1.head: L. Quintius Flamininus
div1.p: brother of the consul Titus, admiral of the fleet on the coast of Greece, 32.16.
Is expelled the senate for barbarous cruelty, 39.42.

div1.head: T. Quintius Barbatus Capitolinus
div1.p: consul, appeases the fury of the populace, 2.56.
Is raised again to the consulship by the patricians, and by a stratagem defeats the Volscians, 64.
Proconsul, rescues the consul from imminent danger, 4, 5.
Pleads in favour of Caeso Quintius, 12, 13.
Quaestor, arraigns Volscius, on whose evidence Caeso had been condemned, 25.
A candidate for the censorship, is disappointed, 35.
He defeats the Aequans and Volscians, 70.
A sixth, he nominates L. Quintius Cincinnatus dictator, 13.
Supplicates the people in favour of T. Quintius, son of Cincinnatus, 41.

div1.head: T. Quintius Cincinnatus Pennus
div1.p: His disputes with his colleague, and activity in the field, 27, 29.
Shares in victory with the dictator, 32, 33.
Is brought to trial, and acquitted, 41.

div1.head: T. Quintius Cincinnatus
div1.p: And in his triumph conveys to the Capitol the image of Imperial Jove, brought from Praeneste.

div1.head: T. Quintius Capitolinus
div1.p: consular tribune, and master of horse, 6.11.

div1.head: T. Quintius
div1.p: chosen as leader by the troops in mutiny, 7.39, 41.

div1.head: T. Quintius Crispinus
div1.p: appointed by Marcellus to the command of a fleet, 24.39.

div1.head: T. Quintius Crispinus
div1.p: his singular encounter with Badius, a Campanian, 25.18.

div1.head: T. Quintius Flamininus
div1.p: curule aedile, exhibits stage plays with great magnificence, 31.4.
Holds a conference with Philip, without effect, 10.
Is obliged to raise the siege of Atrax, 18.
Holds another conference with Philip, which produces a truce, but not a peace, 32, 37.
Proclaims liberty to the states of Greece, 32.
Refuses at first to listen to Nabis, and afterwards grants him peace, 40.
Procures the siege of Naupactum to be raised, 36.35.

div1.head: Quirinus
div1.p: Dedicated, and adorned with spoils of the enemy, 10.46.

div1.head: L. Ramnius
div1.p: a Brundusian, tempted by Perseus to poison the Roman ambassadors and officers, discovers the matter to the Romans, 42.17, 41.

div1.head: Ramnenses
div1.p: or Ramnes, one of the first tribes, and a century of knights, 1.13, 36; 10.6.

div1.head: Regillus
div1.p: lake, near which Postumius routed the Latins, 2.19, 20; 6.2.

div1.head: Religion
div1.p: A passion for foreign religious rites prevails, 4.30.
Religious worship performed with more piety than magnificence, 3.57.
The bad consequences of introducing foreign modes of worship, 25.1.

div1.head: Remus
div1.p: made prisoner, and given up to Amulius; assists in restoring his grandfather, and is slain by his brother, 1.5.

div1.head: Rhegium
div1.p: Furnishes the Romans with a supply of ships, 36.42.

div1.head: Rhion
div1.p: or Rhium, strait between Naupactum and Patrae, being the entrance to the bay of Corinth, 27.30; 28.7.

div1.head: Rhisiasus
div1.p: of Pellene, threatens his son Memnon with death, if he persists in obstructing the proceedings of a council of the Achaeans, 32.22.

div1.head: Rhodians
div1.p: send ambassadors to compose disputes between Philip and the Aetolians, 27.30; 28.7.
Send a fleet to aid the Romans against Philip, 31.46.
Join their fleet to the Roman against Antiochus, 37.9.
Defeat his fleet, commanded by Hannibal, 23.24.
Again, in conjunction with the Romans, defeat Polyxenidas, 30.
Receive Lycia and Caria, after the reduction of Antiochus, 38.39.
Send to the Roman consul a menacing embassy in favour of Perseus, 44.14.
Implore pardon of the Roman ambassadors, and punish the advisers of their misconduct, 45.10.
Juvencius Thalna, praetor, proposes to the Roman commissioners a declaration of war against Rhodes, and is opposed by the tribunes, 21.

div1.head: Rhoduntia
div1.p: one of the summits of mount Oeta, near Thermopylae, 36.16, 18.

div1.head: Rome
div1.p: Augmented by the destruction of Alba, 30.
Sacked and burned by the Gauls, 5.41, 42.
Doubled by the accession of the Sabines, 1.13.

div1.head: Romans
div1.p: Military abilities, 9.17, 19. See Army, Camp, Discipline. They long held poverty in honour, see Poverty. It is the character of a Roman, both to act and to suffer with fortitude, 2.12.

div1.head: T. Romilius
div1.p: consul, brought to trial on a charge made by Cl. Cicero, 3.31.

div1.head: Romulus Sylvius
div1.p: son of Rhea, kills his brother Remus; builds a city on the Palatine hill, and, from his own name, calls it Rome, 1.16.
Forms the government, enlarges the city, opens a sanctuary, and forms a senate, 8.
Orders the seizure of the Sabine women, 9.
Overthrows the Caeninians, killing their king, offers the grand spoils to Jupiter Feretrius. and dedicates to him the first temple in Rome, 10.
Distressed in battle with the Sabines, vows a temple to Jupiter Stator, 12.
Makes peace with the Sabines, and divides the city into thirty curias, 13.
Conquers the Fidentians and Veians, appoints three hundred celeres to guard his person, 15.
Dies, and is esteemed a divinity, 16.

div1.head: L. Roscius
div1.p: Roman ambassador, killed by order of Tolumnius, 4.17.

div1.head: Ruscino
div1.p: where some states of Gaul assembled, with intent to oppose Hannibal, 21.24.

div1.head: P. Rutilius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, warmly opposes the censors, and brings them to trial, 43.16.

div1.head: Sabine women
div1.p: Put an end to the fight between the Romans and Sabines; their names given to the curias, 13.

div1.head: Sabines
div1.p: Maintain a furious fight, and afterwards make a peace, 13.
Are attacked and conquered by T. Hostilius, 30, 31.
Those who removed to Rome with Tatius reside on the Capitol and citadel, 33.
The Sabines are attacked, and defeated by Tarquinius, 36, 37.
Make a predatory inroad as far as the Anio, and are dispersed, 26.
Renew the war, and are defeated, 31.
Join the Veians against Rome, and are overthrown, 53.
Advance to the gates of the city, 63, 64.

div1.head: Sacrifices
div1.p: several extraordinary, perform ed by direction of the Sibylline books 22.57.
The anniversary sacrifice of Ceres omitted after the battle of Cannae, 22.56.

div1.head: Saguntum
div1.p: an opulent city on the Iberus, 21.7.
Besieged and taken by Hannibal, the inhabitants throw their valuables and themselves into a fire, 14, 15.
Spanish hostages are kept at Saguntum, 22.22.
It is retaken by the Romans, and restored to its old inhabitants, 24.42; 28.39.

div1.head: Saguntines
div1.p: threatened by Hannibal, send ambassadors to Rome, 21.2, 6.
Show great firmness in supporting the siege, 11.
Send an embassy to Rome with thanks to the senate, 28.39.

div1.head: Salapia
div1.p: Surrendered to Marcellus with the Carthaginian garrison, 26.38; 27.1.

div1.head: Salii
div1.p: twelve priests of Mars instituted by Numa, 1.20.
Twelve more vowed by Tullus, and called Agonales, or Colline, 27.

div1.head: Sallentines
div1.p: Some of their towns revolt to Hannibal, 25.1.

div1.head: P. Salonius
div1.p: alternately military tribune and chief centurion, entreats the senators not, on his account, to refuse the demands of themutinous soldiers,7.41.

div1.head: Salyi
div1.p: or Salyes, or Salluvii, people of Gaul, 5.35.

div1.head: Samaeans
div1.p: in Cephallenia,break the peace, which had been concluded, and are besieged, 38.28.
After a vigorous defence the city is taken, and sacked, 29.

div1.head: Samnites
div1.p: form an alliance with the Romans 6.19.
Origin of the war between those states, 29.
Ambassadors sent to the Samnites, receive a rude and menacing answer, 31.
A furious battle, in which the Samnites are defeated, 33.
They send ambassadors to sue for peace, 8.1.
They join the Lucanians against Alexander of Epire, 17.
Answer with haughtiness the expestulatians of the Romans, 23.
Defeated by Fabius, master of horse, 30.
Make a truce for a year, break it, and, after a desperate engagement, are defeated, 38, 39.
Entrap the Roman army at the Caudine forks, 9.2.

and after violent exertions, and suffering many defeats, 13–16, 21–23, 27, 31, 40, 41, they submit, and are sent under the yoke, 42. Their gold and silver shielded battalions, 40. The old treaty is renewed with them, 45. They take arms again, and are worsted, 10.12.
Fight a furious battle, and are obliged to fly into Etruria, 16.

They join the Etrurians, Umbrians, and Gauls,21. With the Gauls invade the Roman territories, 27; and are defeated, 29. Their character as soldiers, 28. They are defeated in abloody battle, 31. They assault the Roman camp, 32; and are repulsed, 33. Seven thousand of them are sent under the yoke, 36. Again, by Papirius, 41.42.
They, excepting the Pentrians, revolt to Hannibal, 22.61.
Their country severely ravaged by Marcellus, 23.42.

div1.head: Sardians
div1.p: Send a secret embassy to the Carthaginians, 23.32.

div1.head: Sardinia
div1.p: A Roman army ordered to be sent thither, 41.9.
Are conquered by Sempronius Gracchus, and a picture hung up, 41.28.

div1.head: Sarus river
div1.p: fleet of Antiochus shipwrecked at its mouth, 33.41.

div1.head: Saticula
div1.p: Its inhabitants commended by the Romans, 27.10.

div1.head: Satricum
div1.p: taken from the Romans by Coriolanus, 2.39.
By the Romans from the Volscians, 6.8.
The Antians settle a colony there, and the Romans sack and burn the city, 7.27.

div1.head: Saturnalia
div1.p: Proclaimed to last a day and a night, and to be observed for ever, 22.1.

div1.head: Saturn's temple
div1.p: Sacrifices and a lectisternium at it, 22.1.

div1.head: P. Scaptius
div1.p: persuades the Roman people in a case where they are arbitrators, to assume to themselves some lands in dispute between the Ardeans and Aricians, 3.71.

div1.head: Schoenus
div1.p: merchant, informs Quintius of the roads to Perrhaebia, 44.35.

div1.head: Scopas
div1.p: Carries a large body of troops to Egypt, 31.43.

div1.head: Scorpions
div1.p: engines, the number found in New Carthage, 26.47.

div1.head: C. Scribonius Curio
div1.p: plebeian aedile, prosecutes farmers of the public lands, 33.42.

div1.head: L. Scribonius
div1.p: deputy from the Roman prisoners, taken by Hannibal, 22.61.

div1.head: Scultenna river
div1.p: at which the Ligurians are defeated by C. Claudius, 41.12, 18.

div1.head: Secession of the commons to the Sacred Mount
div1.p: and thence to the Sacred Mount, 52.

div1.head: Sedentary occupations
div1.p: people of, summoned to take arms, 8.20.

div1.head: Seleucus
div1.p: Wastes the country of Pergamus, and lays siege to the city, 37.18.
Is compelled by Diophanes, an Achaean, to retire out of the country, 21.

div1.head: Sempronius Blaesus
div1.p: quaestor, is slain with one thousand of his men, 22.31.

div1.head: A. Sempronius Atratinus
div1.p: one of the first consular tribunes, 4.7.

div1.head: C. Sempronius
div1.p: He is accused by L. Hortensius, plebeian tribune, and saved by the entreaties of the military tribunes of his army, 42.

div1.head: C. Sempronius Blaesus
div1.p: brings to trial Cn. Fulvius, for the loss of his army, 26.2.

div1.head: M. Sempronius Tuditanus
div1.p: on the capture of New Carthage, appointed arbiter in the dispute about a mural crown, 26.48.

div1.head: P. Sempronius
div1.p: Engages in an irregular combat with Hannibal, and is worsted; engages him again, and gains the victory, 36.

div1.head: P. Sempronius Sophus
div1.p: Inveighs against Appius Claudius, censor, and orders him to be imprisoned, 34.

div1.head: P. Sempronius Blaesus
div1.p: plebeian tribune, opposes the grant of a triumph to P. Cornelius Scipio, 36.39.

div1.head: P. Sempronius Gracchus
div1.p: plebeian tribune, and Caius, accuse Acilius Glabrio of peculation, 37.58.

div1.head: Tib. Sempronius Gracchus
div1.p: Sends corn and nuts down the river to the besieged in Casilinum, 23.19.
Supports the spirits of the senate, 25.
Takes the command of the volunteer slaves, 32.
His services, 35–37. He defeats Hanno, 24.14,15. Gives freedom to the volunteer slaves, 16. Again consul, 43. His actions in Lucania, 25.1.
He is insnared by treachery, and his body is sent to Hannibal, 16.

div1.head: Tib. Sempronius Gracchus
div1.p: when very young, is made augur, 29.38.
Chosen, as remarkably spirited, by Scipio, for an expeditious journey to Philip, 37.7.

div1.head: Tib. Sempronius Longus
div1.p: Fights Hannibal again, is successful at first, but worsted afterwards, 59.

div1.head: Tib. Sempronius Gracchus
div1.p: plebeian tribune, although at enmity with Scipio Africanus, stops the prosecution against him, and receives thanks from the senate for his honourable conduct,38.53.
Prevents the imprisonment of L. Scipio, 60.

div1.head: Tib. Sempronius Longus
div1.p: son of Caius, commissioner of religious affairs, 27.6.
Informs the senate of an insurrection in Liguria, 56.

div1.head: Senate
div1.p: instituted by Romans, consisting of one hundred members, called Patres, and their descendants, Patricians, 1.8.
Their number augmented on the destruction of Alba, 1.17, 30.
to two hundred, and to three hundred by the first Tarquinius, called Fathers of Inferior Birth, 35.
Is diminished by the cruelty of Tarquinius the Proud, 49.
Chiefs of the Albans chosen into the senate, 1.30.
The first mention by Livy of a plebeian senator, 5.12.
Appius Claudius procures the admission of sons of freed-men into the senate, but this practice is not followed, 9.46.
The rule altered, which required the senate's previous approbation of a law, before it was passed by the people, 1.17.
Senators chosen first by the kings, 8, 30, 35.
After the battle of Cannae, a dictator created to choose the senate, 23.22.
Prince of the senate generally the member alive who had been censor first, 27.11.
A particular place assigned to senators at the public shows, 34.54.
Decrees of the senate first kept by the aediles in the temple of Ceres, 3.55.
Senators forbidden to deal in merchandise, 21.63.
Liable to a fine for non-attendance, 3.38.

div1.head: Senones
div1.p: people of Gaul, advance to Cluslum, and to Rome, 5.35. See Gauls. Surround and cut to pieces a Roman legion, 10.26.

div1.head: Seppius Lesius
div1.p: the last Campanian who was chief magistrate at Capua, 26.6, 13.

div1.head: Sergia
div1.p: practised in poisoning, put to death by a dose of her own composition, 8.18.

div1.head: L. Sergius
div1.p: carrying an offering to Delphi, taken by pirates, and dismissed, 5.28.

div1.head: Man. Sergius Fidenas
div1.p: On his camp being attacked by the Faliscians, he chooses to be vanquished by the enemy, rather than send to his colleague for succour, for which he is brought to trial, 11.

div1.head: Man. Sergius
div1.p: military tribune, assists in the taking of Locri, 29.6.
Is scourged by Pleminius, and put to death, 9.

div1.head: Man. Sergius Silus
div1.p: praetor, when the number was increased to six, 32.27.

div1.head: Servilii
div1.p: Albans, chosen into the senate by Tullius Hostilius, 1.30.

div1.head: C. Servilius
div1.p: commissioner of lands, obliged to fly by an inroad of the Boians, 21.25.

div1.head: Servilius
div1.p: consular tribune, contending with his colleagues, submits to the advice of his father, 4.45.

div1.head: C. Servilius Ahala
div1.p: Master of horse, and a second time consular tribune, 57.
In obedience to the will of the senate, he obliges his colleagues to abdicate, 9.

div1.head: C. Servilius
div1.p: commissioner for conducting a colony to Placentia, is seized by the Gauls, 21.25.
and sixteen years after is delivered, and brought home by his son, 30.19.

div1.head: C. Servilius
div1.p: son of the preceding, lieutenant-general, throws supplies into the citadel of Tarentum, 25.15.
Master of horse, and curule aedile, 33, 36.
Liberates and brings home his father, 30.19.
Is ordered to find out expiations in time of a pestilence, 40.37.

div1.head: Cn. Servilius Caepio
div1.p: Goes over to Sicily in pursuit of Hannibal, but is recalled by a dictator appointed for the purpose, 24.

div1.head: Cn. Servilius Geminus
div1.p: He ravages the island of Maninx, 31.
Follows the plan of Fabius in conducting the war, 32, 43.

div1.head: M. Servilius
div1.p: His speech in favour of Aemilius Paullus, 45.37, &c.

div1.head: P. Servilius
div1.p: Not pleasing either to the patricians or plebeians, 27.

div1.head: Q. Servilius
div1.p: Again; and is sent against the Aequans, 3.2.

div1.head: Q. Servilius
div1.p: quaestor, prosecutes M. Volscius for false evidence against Caeso, 3.24.

div1.head: Q. Servilius Priscus
div1.p: Routs the Etrurians, and takes Fidenae, 22.
Calls on the tribunes to make the consuls name a dictator, 26.

div1.head: Q. Servilius Ahala
div1.p: Dictator; he, by direction of the senate, vows the great games, and, after several services, abdicates, 11.

div1.head: Sp. Servilius
div1.p: consul, repulses the Veians; is afterwards worsted by them, and saved by his colleague, 2.51, 52.

div1.head: Servius Tullius
div1.p: Son of a prisoner taken at Corniculum, 39.
Advanced to the throne by the senate, 41.
Marries his daughters to the Tarquins. 42.

div1.head: P. Sestius
div1.p: a patrician, brought to trial before the people by C. Julius, decemvir, 3.33.

div1.head: Setia
div1.p: Decree of the senate on the occasion, 29.15.

div1.head: Setians
div1.p: inform of the revolt of the Privernians, 8.1.

div1.head: Sewer
div1.p: great, constructed by Tarquinius the Proud, 1.55.

div1.head: M. Sextilius
div1.p: of Fregellae, answers for eighteen colonies, that they would supply troops, 27.10.

div1.head: Sextius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, proposes laws concerning debts, concerning lands, and the admission of plebeians to the consulship, and prevents the election of curule magistrates, 6.35.
Being a tenth time tribune, he is made the first plebeian consul, 42.

div1.head: Shops of the silversmiths in the Roman forum set up to sale by Hannibal
L. Siccius
div1.p: murdered by contrivance of the decemvirs, 3.43.

div1.head: Sicilians
div1.p: They complain to the senate of Marcellus, 26.29.
The humble supplication of the ambassadors to him, 33.

div1.head: Sicilius
div1.p: who had excited the Hirpinians to a revolt, beheaded, 23.37.

div1.head: Sicily
div1.p: Corn is purchased there by the Romans, 2.34.
The Carthaginians first send an army thither, 4.29.
A fleet sent, as supposed by Livy, by the tyrants of Sicily, infests the Tuscan sea, 7.25.
The island is abandoned by the Carthaginians, 26.40.

div1.head: C. Sicinius
div1.p: advises the secession to the Sacred Mount, 2.32.
Is one of the first plebeian tribunes, 33. See 3.54.

div1.head: Cn. Sicinius
div1.p: Is sent with an army to Macedonia, 27.

div1.head: T. Sicinius
div1.p: proposes that the Romans should remove to Veil, 5.24.

div1.head: Sidicinians
div1.p: attacked by the Samnites, procure the assistance of the Campanians, 7.29.
Wish to surrender themselves to the Romans; and, being rejected, are reduced by the Latins, 8.1, 2.

div1.head: Sigovesus
div1.p: leader of the Celts into Italy, 5.34.

div1.head: Silver
div1.p: accruing from fines, by which brazen images were purchased, and set up in the temple of Ceres, 27.6.

div1.head: Smyrna
div1.p: Is honoured by the Romans, and rewarded with an addition of territory, 38.39.

div1.head: Soldiers
div1.p: Donations usually made to them by a general at his triumph, 10.44.
Their verses, 3.26; 4.40. See Army and Legion.

div1.head: Sopater
div1.p: one of Philip's generals, carries four thousand men to Africa, 30.26.
Is refused to the demand of Philip's ambassadors, 42.

div1.head: Sophonisba
div1.p: daughter of Hasdrubal, wife of Syphax, marries Masinissa, 30.12.

div1.head: Sora
div1.p: Inhabitants kill the Roman colonists, and join the Samnites, 9.23.
It is taken by the Romans, by means of a deserter, 24.
Decree of the senate on its refusing supplies, 29.15.

div1.head: Sosis
div1.p: and Theodotus, as soon as Hieronymus was slain, hasten to Syracuse, 24.21.

div1.head: Sosis
div1.p: sent by Marcellus to the governor of the fort Euryalus, 25.25.
Wears a golden crown in Marcellus's triumph, and is rewarded with the freedom of Rome, 26.21.

div1.head: Spain
div1.p: divided between the Romans and Carthaginians by the river Iberus, 21.2.
Cn. Scipio the first Roman who headed an army there, 21.32; 25.37.
The first conquest attempted on the continent, and the last completed, 28.12.
The inhabitants restless, and fond of change, 22.21.

div1.head: Sparta
div1.p: in early times, had not walls, 34.38.
Its mode of education rough and hardy, 38.17. See Lacedaemon.

div1.head: Spies
div1.p: employed by Hannibal, taken by the Roman guards, are, by the order of Scipio, conducted through all parts of the camp, and dismissed, 30.29.

div1.head: Spoils
div1.p: grand, offered by Romulus to Jupiter Feretrius, 1.10.

div1.head: Spoletum
div1.p: The inhabitants commended by the Romans, 27.10.

div1.head: Spy of the Carthaginians
div1.p: discovered at Rome, had his hands cut off, and was sent away, 22.33.

div1.head: Statiellae
div1.p: a Ligurian city, unjustly attacked by M. Popilius, 42.7, 8, 21.

div1.head: Manius Statilius
div1.p: a Lucanian, detects a stratagem of Hannibal, 22.42, 43.

div1.head: Statius Trebius
div1.p: promises to put Hannibal in possession of Compsa, 33.1.

div1.head: Statius Metius
div1.p: commander of the celebrated garrison of Casilinum, 24.19.

div1.head: Statius Gellius
div1.p: Samnite general, is taken by the Romans, 9.44.

div1.head: Q. Statorius
div1.p: left with Syphax to discipline his troops, 24.48; 30.28.

div1.head: Stenius Minius Celer
div1.p: one of Hannibal's hosts at Capua, 23.8.

div1.head: L. Stertinius
div1.p: commissioner to give liberty to several Thracian states, 33.35.

div1.head: Stratonice
div1.p: a fruitless expedition of the Rhodians against it, 33.18.
It is assigned to the Rhodians by the Romans, 30.

div1.head: Stratonides
div1.p: accomplice of Zeuxippus in a plot against Brachyllas, 33.28.

div1.head: Suessa Aurunca
div1.p: Decree of the senate in consequence, 29.15.

div1.head: Suessulans
div1.p: are complimented with the freedom of Rome without right of suffrage, 8.14.

div1.head: Suffetes
div1.p: title of the chief magistrate at Carthage, 28.37; 30.7.

div1.head: Sulpicia
div1.p: mother-in-law to the consul Postumius, gives him a good character of Aebutia, in the affair of the Bacchanals, 39.11.

div1.head: C. Sulpicius
div1.p: Probably the same with C. Sulpicius Peeticus, consul, 7.2.
Is made dictator, and defers coming to action, to the dissatisfaction of his army, 12.
He defeats the Gauls, and triumphs, 15.
Is made interrex, and a third time consul, 17.
A second time interrex, and a fifth time consul, 22.

div1.head: C. Sulpicius Gallus
div1.p: praetor, is chosen a patron by hither Spain, 43.2.
Military tribune; foretells to the army an eclipse of the moon, 44.37.

div1.head: P. Sulpicius Galba
div1.p: before he had held any curule office, made consul, 25.41.
Is sent into Apulia, and thence to Macedonia, 24.22, 28.

div1.head: Q. Sulpicius Longus
div1.p: Makes terms with Brennus for raising the siege of the Capitol, 48.

div1.head: Sulpicius
div1.p: Deputy to Athens, to collect laws, 31.
Deputy to the seceding troops on the Aventine, 50.

div1.head: Servius Sulpicius
div1.p: His wife daughter of M. Fabius Ambustus, 34.

div1.head: Servius Sulpicius Galba
div1.p: Instigates the second legion to oppose the triumph of P. Aemilius, 45.35.

div1.head: Survey
div1.p:
general, instituted by Ser. Tullius, 1.42.
Performed, 1.44. Number rated 80,000
Performed, 3.3. Number rated 124,214
Performed, 3.24. Number rated 132,409
Performed, 10.9, 47. Number rated 262,322
Performed, 27.36. Number rated 137,108
Performed, 29.37. Number rated 214,000
Performed, 38.36. Number rated 258,308
Performed, 42.10. Number rated 269,015

div1.head: Sutrium
div1.p: taken by Etrurians, and retaken by Camillus, 6.3.
The city is besieged by the Etrurians, and relieved, 9.
Considered as the key of Etruria, and again besieged, 9.32, 35. See 10.14.
Decree of the senate in consequence, 29.15.

div1.head: Sycurium
div1.p: operations of Perseus and the Romans near it, 42.54, 57, 62, 64.

div1.head: Sylvanus
div1.p: supposed to have uttered a loud voice from the Arsian wood, 2.7.

div1.head: Syphax
div1.p: king of Numidia, solicited by Scipio, forms a treaty of amity with the Romans, 24.48.
Defeated by Masinissa, he flies to the Maurusians, 49.
Sends an embassy to Rome, and receives one from thence, 27.4.
Is visited by Scipio and Hasdrubal, and makes an alliance with Scipio, 28.17, 18.
Marries a daughter of Hasdrubal, and renounces the friendship of Scipio, 29.23.
His camp is burned by Scipio and Masinissa, 30.5.
He advances against Masinissa and Laelius; is defeated and taken, 11.
His discourse to Scipio on being brought to the Roman camp, 13.

div1.head: Syracuse
div1.p: suffers great disturbances after the death of Hieronymus, 24.21, 27, 28.
Falls under the command of Hippocrates and Epicydes, 33.
Is besieged by Marcellus, and defended by Archimedes, and the siege turned into a blockade, 34.

div1.head: Syracusans
div1.p: put their city under the patronage of Marcellus, 26.32.

div1.head: Tables
div1.p: Engraved in brass, and hung up in public, 57.

div1.head: Talassio
div1.p: whence the practice of repeating this word at weddings, 1.9.

div1.head: Tanaquil
div1.p: wife of Lucumo, skilled in augury, 1.34.
Advises her husband to give the best education to Servius Tullius, 39.
Conceals the death of Tarquinius until Servius secures the throne, 41. See 47.

div1.head: Tarentines
div1.p: engage the Lucanians in a war against Rome, 8.27.
Their insolent embassy derided by Papirius, 9.14.
Their hostages, apprehended in flight from Rome, are thrown from the Tarpeian rock, 25.7.
They join the enemy, 8, &c. Their fleet defeats that of the Romans, while the Romans defeat their army on land, 26.39.

div1.head: Tarentum
div1.p: Its defence provided for by the Romans, 15.

div1.head: Sp. Tarpeius
div1.p: commander in the citadel of Rome; his daughter, bribed by T. Tatius, admits the Sabines into the fortress, 1.11.

div1.head: Tarpeius
div1.p: accused, on the expiration of his consulate, 3.31.
Is one of the deputies sent to the seceders on the Aventine, 50.

div1.head: Tarquinians
div1.p: take arms in favour of Tarquinius the Proud; and, after a battle with the Romans, 2.6.
Ravage the Roman territory, are defeated, and treated with severity for having massacred Roman soldiers, 19.
A truce of forty years is granted to them, 22.
The Tarquinians and Taliscians defeat the consul Fabius by means of snakes and burning torches, 7.17.

div1.head: L. Tarquinius Priscus
div1.p: appointed tutor to the king's sons, forms designs on the throne, 1.34.
Is elected king, adds one hundred to the senate, wages war with the Latins, 35.

div1.head: L. Tarquinius
div1.p: Instigated by his wife, seizes it by force, 47.

Puts the principal senators to death, secures his person by a strong guard, neglects the practice of consulting the senate, courts the favour of the Latins, marries his daughter to Mamilius of Tusculum, is surnamed the Proud, 49.
He makes war on the Volscians, and takes Suessa Pometia; takes Gabii by stratagem, 53, 54.
Builds the temple of Jupiter Capitolinus, and executes other works, 55.
Attempts to recover the kingdom by the aid of the Veians and Tarquinians, 2.6.
then of Porsenna, and is wounded at the battle of Regillus, 19.

div1.head: Tarquinius Aruns
div1.p: son of the Proud, sent to Delphi, 1.56.
Falls in battle, together with his antagonist L. J. Brutus, 2.6.

div1.head: L. Tarquinius
div1.p: Is present in the battle of Regillus, 2.19, 20.

div1.head: Sex. Tarquinius
div1.p: son of the same, betrays Gabii to his father, 1.53, 54.

div1.head: Auruns Tarquinius
div1.p: brother of the Proud, mild in disposition, is murdered by his wife, 1.46.

div1.head: L. Tarquinius Collatinus
div1.p: son of Egerius, husband of Lucretia, 1.57.

div1.head: Tarraco
div1.p: An assembly of all the Spanish allies is held there by Scipio, 26.19.

div1.head: Taurinians
div1.p: their capital city taken by Hannibal, 21.39.

div1.head: Taxes
div1.p: remitted to the commons of Rome, 2.9.
Imposed for payment of the army, and collected in spite of the tribunes, 4.60.
A tax for building a wall of hewn stone, 6.32.

div1.head: Tectosagian Gauls settle in the inland part of Asia
div1.p: Form an ambush for the Roman consul, 25.
Ordered not to carry arms beyond their own bounds, 40.

div1.head: Sex. Tempanius
div1.p: decurio of horse, by making the cavalry dismount, prevents a total defeat, 4.38.
His prudent answer respecting the consul Sempronius, 41.

div1.head: Tempe
div1.p: A meeting there of Cn. Cornelius and Philip, 33.35; 36.10; 42.67; 44.6, 7.

div1.head: Teos
div1.p: Is plundered by the Romans, and compelled to furnish supplies, 28.
A naval victory gained there by the Romans over Antiochus, 30.

div1.head: C. Terentillus Arsa
div1.p: plebeian tribune, proposes the creation of five commissioners to compose laws for restraining the power of the consuls, 3.9.

div1.head: C. Terentius
div1.p:
of mean birth, proposes an order of the people, giving the master of horse authority equal to that of the dictator. and is made consul, xxii.
25, 35. Disagreement between him and his colleague Aemilius, 41.44.
Gives the signal of battle at Cannae, 45.
At his return to Rome, receives general thanks, 61.
His speech to the Campanian deputies, 23.5.
He is continued in command during several years, 25.6; 27.35.

div1.head: L. Terentius
div1.p: sent one of ten deputies to adjust a dispute between Antiochus and Ptolemy, 33.39.

div1.head: Q. Terentius Culleo
div1.p: a senator, after having been long a prisoner of the Carthaginians, is restored to his country, 30.43.
Is commissioned to hold an inquiry respecting the conduct of Scipio, 55.

div1.head: Thaumaci
div1.p: besieged by Philip, relieved by the Aetolians, 32.4.

div1.head: Thebes
div1.p: It is seized by T. Quintius, 33.1, 2.
The inhabitants divided into two parties, the stronger of which surrenders the city to the Romans, 42.44.
The Romans again take possession of it, 63.

div1.head: Thebes
div1.p: Retained by the Romans, in opposition to the Aetolians, 33.13; 39.25.

div1.head: Themistus
div1.p: son-in-law of Gelon, accomplice of Andranodorus, put to death, 24.24, 25.

div1.head: Thensae
div1.p: carriages for the images of the gods, 5.41; 9.40.

div1.head: Theodotus
div1.p: one of the conspirators against Hieronymus, when put to the torture, conceals his accomplices, and falsely accuses Thraso, 24.5.
Hastens with Sosis to Syracuse, after the death of Hieronymus, 21.

div1.head: Theondas
div1.p: king of Samothrace, summons Evander of Crete to stand trial for murder, is bribed afterwards by Perseus, 45.5.

div1.head: Theoxena
div1.p: daughter of Herodicus, a Thessalian chieftain, her extraordinary affection for the children of her sister Archo, and her courageous death, 40.4.

div1.head: Thermopylae
div1.p: why so called, rendered memorable by the efforts of the Lacedaemonians against the Persians, 38.15.
Defeat of Antiochus near it, 18, 19. See 42, and 45.22.

div1.head: Thesprotians assist Ap. Claudius in Epirus
Thessalians
div1.p: Are answered by him in a menacing manner, 26.
Raise insurrections on account of debts, 42.5.

div1.head: Thessalonice
div1.p: a congress held there, concerning Thracian cities seized by Philip, 39.27; 40.56.

div1.head: Thessaly
div1.p: Its rich plains tempt the Aetolians, 31.41.
It is plundered by three armies at once, 32.14, 15.
Philip defeated there by T. Quintius, 33.7, 8, 24.

div1.head: Thoas
div1.p: praetor of the Aetolians, persuades them to engage Antiochus, Philip, and Nabis, in alliance against the Romans, 35.12.
Opposes Phaeneas's proposal of an accommodation. 45.
Is required to be given up to the Romans, 38.38.

div1.head: Thracians
div1.p: attack the troops of Manlius on their march, 38.40, 41, 46.
Consent to give a passage to the Bastarnians, 40.57.
On the death of Philip, quarrel with and expel them, 58.
Send ambassadors to Rome, and form an alliance and friendship, 42.19.
Wage frequent wars with the Macedonians, 52.
Attack the Roman cavalry with extraordinary fury, 59.
Send an embassy to Rome to ransom prisoners, and obtain them without ransom, 45.42.

div1.head: Thrasians
div1.p: plunderers, put to flight by the Romans, 38.41.

div1.head: Thrasimene
div1.p: or Trasimene, lake, the battle near it, 22.6, 7; 24.13.

div1.head: Thrasippus
div1.p: Macedonian, commander of a chosen band of targeteers, 42.51.

div1.head: Thraso
div1.p: intimate friend of Hieronymus, king of Syracuse, falsely accused as a conspirator, and put to death, 24.5.

div1.head: Thronium
div1.p: a conference held there be tween Philip and Quintius, 32.36; 35.37; 36.20.

div1.head: Thunder
div1.p: being heard while an assembly is held, vitiates the proceedings, 23.31.

div1.head: Thuriae
div1.p: Having revolted to Hannibal, returns to its former friendship with Rome, 25.1.
Revolts again to Hannibal, the Roman garrison being treacherously exposed to Hannibal's stratagem, 15.

div1.head: Thyrium
div1.p: Refusing an alliance with Antiochus, is besieged by him, but the siege is soon raised, 12.
A council of the Acarnanians held there, to give audience to Roman commissioners, 43.17.

div1.head: Tiber
div1.p: or Tiberinus, river, formerly Albula, until king Tiberinus was drowned in it, 1.3.
Frozen so hard, that the navigation is stopped, 5.13.
Two bridges and many buildings in Rome destroyed, 21.
The field of Mars and low parts of the city overflowed twelve times in one year, 38.28.

div1.head: Tiburtians
div1.p: war declared against them by the Romans, 7.9.
who gain a victory over them, 11.
They come in the dead of the night to the walls of Rome, and are defeated, 12.
Compelled to submit to the Romans, 19.
And stripped of part of their lands, 14.

div1.head: Timasitheus
div1.p: commander of the Liparean pirates, protects the Roman ambassadors, 5.28.

div1.head: Timon
div1.p: a person of consequence in Phthiotic Thebes, 33.5.

div1.head: Timon
div1.p: made governor of Lydia by Antiochus, 37.44.

div1.head: Titienses
div1.p: a century of Roman knights, and an old tribe, 1.13, 36; 10.6.

div1.head: L. Titinius
div1.p: Again, he is unsuccessful against the Faliscians, 18.

div1.head: M. Titinius
div1.p: and C., plebeian tribunes, oppose the suit of L. Cornelius for a triumph, 35.8.

div1.head: Tolumnius
div1.p: Lars, king of the Veians, orders the Roman ambassadors to be slain, 4.17.
Is killed in battle by Cornelius Cossus, military tribune, 19.

div1.head: Tralles
div1.p: in Asia, surrendered to the Romans, 37.45.

div1.head: Q. Treasury
div1.p: centurion, claims the mural crown at New Carthage, 26.48.

div1.head: Trebius
div1.p: procures the surrender of Compsa to Hannibal, 23.1.

div1.head: L. Trebonius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, a bitter adversary to the patricians, thence surnamed Asper, 3.65.

div1.head: Cn. Tremellius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, protests against the censors being continued in office, 45.15.

div1.head: Tribunes
div1.p: military, on the secession of the soldiers, are appointed by the troops, 3.51.

div1.head: Tribunes
div1.p: military, at first appointed by the generals, afterwards in part by the people, 7.5; 9.30.

div1.head: Tribunes
div1.p: consular, three in number, first elected, 4.67.

div1.head: Tribunes
div1.p: Magistrates of the commons, not of the people at large, 2.35, 56.
Ordered to be elected in an assembly of the tribes, and three added to their number, 56, 58.
The office laid aside on the creation of decemvirs, 32.

Two are brought in by choice of their college,
64, and 5.10.
A plebeian tribune orders his beadle to seize a consul, 2.56.
The tribunes threaten to imprison the consuls, 4.26.
Do the same to the consular tribunes, 5.9.
Prevent the election of curule magistrates during five years, 6.35.
Their power confined within the walls of the city, 3.20.

div1.head: Tricca
div1.p: Disputed by Philip and the Thessalians, 39.25.

div1.head: Triphylia
div1.p: restored to the Achaeans by Philip, 28.8; 32.5.

div1.head: Triumph
div1.p: The dress of generals in triumph, 10.7.
The granting of a triumph belongs properly to the senate, 3.63.
A triumph ordered by the people, without the approbation of the senate, 3.63; 7.17.
One without an order of either, 10.37.

div1.head: Triumph
div1.p: not allowed to a commander, who was not invested with any magistracy, 28.38.

div1.head: Trocmi
div1.p: one of the three tribes of Gauls that migrated to Asia, 38.16.

div1.head: Troy taken; two other places named Troy
Tullia
div1.p: two of the name, daughters of Servius Tullius, king, 1.46–59.

div1.head: Sex. Tullius
div1.p: chief centurion a seventh time, addresses the dictator Sulpicius on his protracting the war, 7.13.

div1.head: Tunes
div1.p: a strong city, fifteen miles distant from Carthage, taken by Scipio, 30.9, 16.

div1.head: Turdetans
div1.p: or Turdulians, a restless people in Spain, 21.6.
Are entirely subdued by the Romans, sold by auction, and their city razed, 24.42.
They are defeated by P. Manlius, 34.17, 19.

div1.head: Tusculum
div1.p: Taken by the Latins, and recovered, 6.33.

div1.head: Tusculans
div1.p: War declared against them by the Romans, which they avoid by peaceable demeanour, obtain peace, and privileges of Roman citizens, 6.25, 26; 8.14, 37.

div1.head: Uffugum
div1.p: revolts from the Carthaginians to the Romans, 30.19.

div1.head: Ulysses
div1.p: said to be the progenitor of Octavius Mamilius, 1.49.

div1.head: Umbria
div1.p: Part of it called the Materine tract, 9.41.

div1.head: Umbrians
div1.p: are driven out of their country by the Boians, 5.35.
They, and the Etrurians, are defeated by the Romans at the Cirninian forest, 9.37.
They boast that they will attack Rome, are vanquished, and compelled to give up the advisers of their revolt, 41.
They join the Etrurians, Samnites, and Gauls, against the Romans, 10.21, 27.

div1.head: Urbicua
div1.p: taken by Fulvius with great difficulty, 40.16.

div1.head: Urites
div1.p: people, furnish ships to the Romans for the Macedonian war, 42.48.

div1.head: Uscana
div1.p: in Illyria, where Appius Claudius is insnared by the garrison, and suffers severely, 43.10.
It is taken by Perseus after an obstinate defence, 18.
Perseus, in violation of the capitulation, sells the natives, and confines the Romans, 19.

div1.head: Utica
div1.p: Lays siege to it, and retires, 35.
His fleet is attacked by the Carthaginians, 9, 10.

div1.head: Vadimon lake
div1.p: a furious battle fought there by the Romans and Etrurians, 9.39.

div1.head: C. Valerius Flaccus
div1.p: made flamen of Jupiter against his will, assumes a seat in the senate, 27.8.
Made curule aedile, he cannot take the requisite oath, 31.50.

div1.head: L. Valerius
div1.p: quaestor, accuses Spurius Cassius of treason, 2.41.

div1.head: L. Valerius
div1.p: deputed to carry to Delphi an offering to Apollo, is taken by pirates, and set at liberty, 5.28.

div1.head: L. Valerius Potitus
div1.p: commences an opposition to the decemvirs, 3.39, 41.
With M. Horatius, drives Appius out of the forum, 49.
Is deputed by the senate to the commissioners, 53.
Made consul, he procures laws in favour of the commissioners, 55.
He triumphs by order of the people, without consent of the senate, 63.
Refuses to be continued in office, 64. See 4.6.

div1.head: L. Valerius Potitus
div1.p: Consul, he defeats the Aequans, and triumphs, 31.

div1.head: L. Valerius Flaccus
div1.p: Proconsul, he entirely vanquishes the Boians and Insubrians, 46.

div1.head: L. Valerius Flaccus
div1.p: with L. Valerius Tappus, commissioners of colonies, 37.46, 57.

div1.head: L. Valerius Flaccus
div1.p: chosen censor with Cato, in opposition to the nobility, 39.41.

div1.head: M. Valerius
div1.p: herald, ratifies a treaty in form, 1.24.

div1.head: Man. Valerius
div1.p: brother of Poplicola, consul, triumphs over the Sabines, 2.16.
Is slain at Regillus in attempting to kill Tarquinius, 20.

div1.head: Man. Valerius
div1.p: Triumphs over the Sabines, and, not being suffered to fulfil the hopes that he had given to the commissioners, abdicates, 31.

div1.head: Man. Valerius
div1.p: military tribune, gains the surname of Corvus, from being aided by a crow in a single combat with a Gaul, and is made consul at twentythree years of age, 7.26.
A second time consul, he triumphs over the Volscians, 27.
Composes a mutiny of the troops, 40, 41.
A fourth time consul, he triumphs over the Ausonians, 8.16.

div1.head: M. Valerius Laevinus
div1.p: Proprietor, he guards the coast at Brundusium, 24.10.
His exploits in Greece during the Macedonian war, 40.
He is chosen consul in his absence, 22.
Persuades the senators to contribute their gold, silver, and money to the treasury, 36.
Drives the Carthaginians quite out of Sicily, 40.
Disputes with the senate about the nomination of a dictator, 27.5.
Proconsul, he passes from Sicily into Africa, 28.4.
Proposes restitution of the moneycontributed by private citizens, 16.
Remarkable funeral games are exhibited in honour of him by his sons, 31.50.

div1.head: M. Valerius Messala
div1.p: admiral, sails to Africa, and ravages the coast, 27.5.

div1.head: P. Valerius
div1.p: son of Volesus, accompanies Collatinus to Lucretia, 1.58.
Is made consul in the place of Collitenus, 2.2.

Is accused of aiming at sovereignty, clears himself, compliments the people, and is surnamed Publicola; is also made consul,
8. A third time, 15. A fourth, he defeats the Sabines, triumphs, and dies so poor, as not to leave sufficient money for his funeral, 16.

div1.head: P. Valerius Publicola
div1.p: Attempts to recover the Capitol from Herdonius, and is slain, 18.

div1.head: Veian lands
div1.p: are divided among the commons of Rome, 5.30.

div1.head: Veians
div1.p: make incursions on the Roman territories, and are routed by Romulus, 1.15.
Again, by Tullus, 27. See 30,42. They assist Tarquinius, 2.6.
Waste the lands of the Romans, 43.

They kill the ambassadors sent from Rome, and renew the war with bad success, 4.17–19. Force the Romans to retire, 31; but are afterwards routed, 33. Obtain a truce of twenty years, 35. Their senate gives a haughty answer to Roman ambassadors, 58; on which the Romans declare war, 60. The Veians elect a king, which disgusts the Etrurians, 5.1.

div1.head: Veii
div1.p: Transactions of the siege, 7–21; when it is taken by Camillus after a siege of ten years, 22. A design formed at Rome of removing to Veii causes great commotions, 24, 25, 29; is laid aside, 30. The relics of the fight at Cannae fly to Veii, 37. Camillus marches thence to recover Rome, 46, 48. The proposal of removing to Veii is renewed, 49, 50; rejected, 55. Such as had gone thither, are recalled, 6.4.
A tenth part of the spoils of Veii vowed to Apollo by Camillus, 5.21. See 23, 25, 28.

div1.head: Velitrans
div1.p: Attack Tusculum, and are invested by the Romans, 36–42. Plunder the Roman territory, 7.15.
Are treated with severity on account of their many revolts, and banished beyond the Tiber, 14.

div1.head: Veneti
div1.p: in Italy, descended from the Heneti and Trojans, 1.1.
Live round the bottom of the Adriatic Gulf, 5.33; 10.2.

div1.head: Venus
div1.p: Her temple, near the Circus, built out of fines levied for breach of chastity, 10.31.

div1.head: Venusians
div1.p: give a hospitable reception to the fugitives from Cannae, 22.54.
Maintain their loyalty to the Romans during a general defection, 27.10.

div1.head: Vercellius
div1.p: beheaded for promoting a revolt of the Hirpinians, 23.37.

div1.head: Vergium
div1.p: a fort in Spain, a receptacle of robbers, is taken by Cato; the robbers are put to death, and the guilty part of the inhabitants sold, 34.21.

div1.head: Vermina
div1.p: son of Syphax, forces Masinissa to fly, 29.33.
Submits the conditions of peace to the Romans, 19.

div1.head: Verulans
div1.p: Prefer their own laws to the rights of Roman citizens, 43.

div1.head: Vescia
div1.p: Comes into the hands of the Romans, 9.25.

div1.head: Vesta
div1.p: a couch for her at a feast of the gods, 22.10.
The fatal pledge of the Roman empire is kept in her temple, which is saved by some slaves from being burnt, 26.27.

div1.head: Vestal
div1.p: Rhea Sylvia, mother of Romulus, is made one, 1.3, 4.

div1.head: Vestal virgins
div1.p: chosen by Numa, have a stipend appointed, and many privileges are conferred on them, 1.20.

div1.head: Vestal virgins
div1.p: with the sacred stores, are carried to Caere by L. Albinius, 5.40.

div1.head: Vestal
div1.p: a, accused, is dismissed, with a charge to be more serious in conversation, and more grave in her dress, 4.44.

div1.head: Vestal
div1.p: convicted of a breach of chastity, is buried alive, 8.15.

div1.head: Vestal
div1.p: who had the charge of the sacred fire, when it was extinguished, is scourged to death, 28.11.
Of two vestals found guilty of incontinence, one is buried alive at the Colline gate, the other kills herself, 22.57.

div1.head: Vestia Oppia
div1.p: a woman of Atellae, who had offered daily sacrifices for the prosperity of the Romans, is restored to her liberty and property, 26.33, 34.

div1.head: Vestians
div1.p: join the Samnites, are routed and dispersed, 8.29.
An alliance is granted on their petition, 10.3.

div1.head: Veturia
div1.p: mother of Coriolanus, prevails on him to retire from Rome, 2.40.

div1.head: L. Veturius Philo
div1.p: Is sent home from Africa, and recounts the exploits of Scipio, 30.38, 40.

div1.head: T. Veturius Calvinus
div1.p: Is sent under the yoke of Caudium, 6.
Offered as prisoner to the Sabines, 10.

div1.head: T. Veturius Geminus
div1.p: consul, routs and disperses the Volscians, 3.8.

div1.head: Vibius Accuaeus
div1.p: prefect of a Pelignian cohort, throws the standard into the enemy's camp, 25.14.

div1.head: Vibius Virius
div1.p: one of the Campanian ambassadors to the consul Varro, persuades his countrymen to join the Carthaginians, 23.6.
Exhorts the senators to put an end to their lives, 26.13.
He and twenty-seven senators swallow poison, 14.

div1.head: Vibius Accuaeus
div1.p: a Bruttian of distinction, comes ambassador to Rome with offers of submission, 27.15.

div1.head: Victory
div1.p: her temple, built with money accruing from fines, 10.33.
A golden image of Victory, weighing three hundred and twenty pounds, sent by Hiero to the Roman senate, 22.37.

div1.head: Q. Victorius
div1.p: chief centurion, throws a standard among the enemy, 34.46.

div1.head: Victumviae
div1.p: Is taken with great slaughter of the inhabitants, 57.

div1.head: Villa publica
div1.p: house for lodging ambassadors and strangers of note, built, 4.22.

div1.head: P. Villius Tappulus
div1.p: is raised from the office of plebeian aedile to that of praetor, 29.38.

div1.head: P. Villius
div1.p: a commissioner to adjust a dispute between Antiochus and Ptolemy, 33.39.
Tappulus, P., commissioner of lands for Scipio's soldiers, 31.4.

div1.head: Vindicius
div1.p: a slave, discovers a conspiracy formed for restoring the Tarquinii, 2.4.
Is rewarded with liberty, and a sum of money, 5.

div1.head: Virginia
div1.p: daughter of Aulius, a patrician, married to Volumnius, a plebeian consul, being excluded from the temple of Patrician Chastity, dedicates a chapel and altar to Plebeian Chastity, 10.23.

div1.head: Virginia
div1.p: daughter of Lucius, her unfortunate beauty, lamentable death, and the punishment of her persecutors, 3.44, 48, 58.

div1.head: Virginius
div1.p: plebeian tribune, commences a capital prosecution against Caeso Quintius, which causes violent contentions, 3.11, 13.

div1.head: Virginius is
div1.p: brought to trial and fined, for having in his tribuneship favoured the senate, 5.29.

div1.head: L. Virginius
div1.p: His contest with Appius about his daughter, 47.
He advises the soldiers to elect ten military tribunes, and refuses to be one, 51.
and orders him to be imprisoned, 57.
Remits the capital punishment of Claudius, who had claimed Virginia, 58.

div1.head: L. Virginius
div1.p: consular tribune, out of enmity neglects assisting his colleague Servius, 5.8.
Both are compelled to re sign the office, 9.
He is brought to trial by a plebeian tribune, and fined, 11, 12.

div1.head: Opiter Virginius
div1.p: consul, with his colleague, takes Pometia, and triumphs, 2.17.

div1.head: Proculus Virginius
div1.p: consul, maintains a contest with his colleague about the Agrarian law, 2.41.

div1.head: Vitellia
div1.p: A Roman colony taken by the Aequans, 5.29.

div1.head: Vitellii
div1.p: brothers, conspirators in favour of the Tarquinii, 2.4.

div1.head: Vitruvius Vaccus
div1.p: of Fundae, general of the Privernians, 8.19.
Is scourged, and put to death by the Romans, his house razed, and his property confiscated to Semo Sanchus, 20.
The site of his house on the Palatine is called Vacciprata.

div1.head: Volae
div1.p: or Bolae, belonging to the Aequans, 4.49, 51; 6.2.

div1.head: Volatenae
div1.p: The inhabitants promise Scipio rigging for his ships, and corn, 28.45.

div1.head: Volcans oppose Hannibal's passing of the Rhone
Volero
div1.p: see Publilius. The tribunes called Voleros by Appius Claudius, 2.58.

div1.head: Volones
div1.p: Gracchus promises them liberty, on condition of their bringing the heads of the enemies, 24.14.
Gracchus orders their public feast, at Beneventum, to be represented in painting; hangs up the picture in the temple of Liberty, 16; 25.20; 27.38; 28.46.

div1.head: Volscians
div1.p: They prepare to assist the Latins, but give hostages, yet secretly prepare for war, 22.
Renew the war, and are conquered, 30.
Deprived of part of their lands, 31.
At the instigation of Attius Tullus they take arms against the Romans, 38.39.
Are led to Rome by Coriolanus, 40.
Are conquered, and treated with the harshest severity, 53.
A truce of forty years is granted to them, 54.
Attack their camp, and are severely beaten, 64, 65.
They invade the Roman territory, are utterly routed, and the nation is almost extirpated, 3.7, 8.
They renew the war in conjunction with the Aequans, 10.
They lay siege to Ardea, and are surrounded by the Romans, 4.9.
Beaten, and sent under the yoke, 10.
They again join the Aequans against the Romans, 26.
Their own camp is taken, and all the prisoners, except senators, are sold as slaves, 29.
Break the peace, and are reduced to submission by Camillus, 6.2.
Meet the same fate in two subsequent efforts, 6, 8, 11, 13.
Join the Praenestines, and take Satricum, 22.
They desert Hannibal, and submit to the Romans, 27.15.

div1.head: Volscians and Aequans
div1.p: so often conquered, still found recruits for their armies this is accounted for, 6.12.

div1.head: Volscians and Aequans
div1.p: people in Spain, their much approved answer to the Roman ambassadors, 21.19.

div1.head: M. Volscius Fictor
div1.p: appears as a witness against Caeso Quintius, 3.13.
Is prosecuted for false evidence by the quaestors, 24.

div1.head: Volsinians
div1.p: make inroads on the Roman territory, 5.31.
Are defeated, and obtain a truce of twenty years, 32.
They use nails, fixed in the temple of the goddess Nortia, as a registry of the years, 7.3.

div1.head: Voltumna
div1.p: A general assembly of Etruria is summoned thither, 4.23, 25; 5.17.
A conspiracy against the Romans is formed there, 6.2.

div1.head: L. Volumnius
div1.p: consul, gets the better of the Sallentines, 9.42.
He leaves his own province to succour Appius Claudius, and, after some altercation, they gain a glorious victory, 18, 19.
He surprises the Samnites who had plundered Campania, 20, 21.
Shows remarkable moderation and prudence at the elections, 21.
and acts with success in Samnium, 30, 31.

div1.head: P. Volumnius
div1.p: Ambassador to the Aequans, he is insulted by their leader, Gracchus Cloelius, 25.

div1.head: Voluntary contribution to the treasury by the senators
Vulcan
div1.p: the arms and spoils of the enemy dedicated to him, and burned, 1.37; 8.10.
His temple in the field of Mars, 24.10.
Arms of the Carthaginians, offered to him by Scipio, 30.6.

div1.head: Vulturnus river
div1.p: Fort at its mouth, afterwards a city, 25.20, 22.

div1.head: Vulturnus river
div1.p: a city of the Etrurians, seized by the Samnites, and called Capua, 4.57.

div1.head: Vulturnus wind
div1.p: blows dust into the eyes of the Romans at Cannae, 22.46.

div1.head: Watches
div1.p: the night divided into four, the first, 5.44.

div1.head: Watches
div1.p: posted in all the streets of Rome, 10.4.

div1.head: Widows
div1.p: their taxes assigned to the maintenance of horses for the knights, 1.43.
Their money lent to the public, 24.18.

div1.head: Wine
div1.p: for sacrifices supplied by the public, 10.23.

div1.head: Wolf
div1.p: said to have suckled Romulus and Remus, 1.4.
Images of the wolf and infants, 10.23.

div1.head: Xenarchus
div1.p: praetor of the Achaeans, wishes to ingratiate himself with Perseus, 41.23.

div1.head: Xenoclides
div1.p: governor of Chalcis, disappoints an attempt of Thoas and the Aetolians, 35.38.

div1.head: Xenophanes
div1.p: head of an embassy from Philip to Hannibal, is taken by a party of Romans, and escapes through an artful fiction, 23.3.
Is taken again, and conveyed to Rome, 34.38.

div1.head: Xenophon
div1.p: Achaean chief, accompanies Quintius at a conference with Philip, 32.33.

div1.head: Xychus
div1.p: accomplice of Perseus in compassing the ruin of Demetrius, forges letters under the signature of Flamininus, 40.55.

div1.head: Year
div1.p: is divided by Numa into twelve lunar months, 1.19.

div1.head: Years
div1.p: reckoned among the Volsinians by nails fixed in the wall of a temple, 7.3.

div1.head: Yoke
div1.p: A Roman army sent under it, 9.5.

div1.head: Youth
div1.p: A feast of the gods in honour of her, 21.62.

div1.head: Zacynthus
div1.p: Is given up to the Romans, 36.32.

div1.head: Zama
div1.p: five days' journey from Carthage; here Scipio defeated Hannibal, 30.29.

div1.head: Zeno
div1.p: supplicates T. Quintius in favour of his countrymen the Magnetians, 35.31.
is made governor of Apamea by Antiochus, 37.44.

div1.head: Zeuxides
div1.p: praetor of Acarnania, is deposed for favouring the Romans, 33.16.

div1.head: Zoippus
div1.p: son-in-law of Hiero, guardian of Hieronymus, 24.4, 5.
Being sent ambassador to Egypt, he remains in voluntary exile, and his wife and daughters are murdered by the Syracusans, 26.

div1.head: Zyboea
div1.p: holds part of Bithynia in opposition to Nicomedes, and is conquered by the aid of the Gauls, 38.16.
